Komberg, Andrey V. Kravstov and Vladimir N. Lukash |} {{Anchor|List of largest-known voids}} ==List of largest voids== [[Void (astronomy)|Void]]s are immense spaces between galaxy filaments and other large-scale structures. Technically they are not structures. They are vast spaces which contain very few, or no galaxies. They are theorized to be caused by quantum fluctuations during the early formation of the universe. A list of the largest voids so far discovered is below. Each is ranked according to its longest dimension. {| class="wikitable sortable" |+'''List of the largest voids''' |- ! style="background:#efefef; white-space:nobr;"| Void name/designation ! style="background:#ffdead;"| Maximum dimension
(in [[light-year]]s) ! Notes |- | [[KBC Void]] || 2,000,000,000 || Void containing the [[Milky Way]] galaxy and [[Local Group]] |- | [[The Giant Nothing]] || 1,800,000,000{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} || |- | [[Giant Void]] || 1,300,000,000 || Also known as ''[[Canes Venatici]] Supervoid'' |- | [[Tully-11 void]] || 880,000,000 || Catalogued by R. Brent Tully |- | [[Tully-10 void]] || 792,000,000 || Catalogued by R. Brent Tully |- | [[Tully-9 void]] || 746,000,000 || Catalogued by R. Brent Tully |- | [[B&B Abell-20 void]] || 684,000,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-9 void]] || 652,000,000 || |- | [[Tully-7 void]] || 567,240,000 || Catalogued by R. Brent Tully |- | [[Tully-4 void]] || 564,000,000 || Catalogued by R. Brent Tully |- | [[Tully-6 void]] || 557,460,000 || Catalogued by R. Brent Tully |- | [[Tully-8 void]] || 554,200,000 || Catalogued by R. Brent Tully |- | [[B&B Abell-21 void]] || 521,600,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-28 void]] || 521,600,000 || |- | [[CMB cold spot#Supervoid|Eridanus Supervoid]] || 489,000,000
(''most likely value'') || A recent analysis of the [[Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe]] (WMAP) in 2007 has found an irregularity of the temperature fluctuation of the [[cosmic microwave background]] within the vicinity of the constellation [[Eridanus (constellation)|Eridanus]] with analysis found to be 70 [[Kelvin|microkelvins]] cooler than the average CMB temperature. One speculation is that a void could cause the cold spot, with the possible size on the left. However, it may be as large as 1 billion light-years, close to the size of the Giant Void. |- | [[B&B Abell-4 void]] || 489,000,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-15 void]] || 489,000,000 || |- | [[Tully-3 void]] || 489,000,000 || Catalogued by R. Brent Tully |- | [[1994EEDTAWSS-10 void]] || 469,440,000 || |- | [[Tully-1 void]] || 456,400,000 || Catalogued by R. Brent Tully |- | [[B&B Abell-8 void]] || 456,000,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-22 void]] || 456,000,000 || |- | [[Tully-2 void]] || 443,360,000 || Catalogued by R. Brent Tully |- | [[B&B Abell-24 void]] || 423,800,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-27 void]] || 423,800,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-7 void]] || 391,200,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-12 void]] || 391,200,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-29 void]] || 391,200,000 || |- | [[1994EEDTAWSS-21 void]] || 378,160,000 || |- | [[Southern Local Supervoid]] || 365,120,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-10 void]] || 358,600,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-11 void]] || 358,600,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-13 void]] || 358,600,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-17 void]] || 358,600,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-19 void]] || 358,600,000 || |- | [[B&B Abell-23 void]] || 358,600,000 || |- | [[1994EEDTAWSS-19 void]] || 342,100,000 || |- | [[Boötes void]] || 330,000,000 || |- | [[1994EEDTAWSS-12 void]] || 328,000,000 || |} ==See also== {{cmn|colwidth=30em| * [[List of most massive black holes]] * [[List of largest galaxies]] * [[List of largest nebulae]] * [[List of largest stars]] * [[List of largest exoplanets]] }} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Large-scale structure of the cosmos|*]] [[Category:Lists of superlatives in astronomy|Structures, largest]] [[Category:Lists of astronomical objects|Largest structures]]

page.title: List of natural gas and oil production accidents in the United States

revision.comment: /* Louisiana */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: between 300 to → between 300 and
revision.text:
This article is intended as a companion to the Wikipedia article List of pipeline accidents in the United States. Large accidents, reported in the Wikipedia article, Industrial Disasters, are included. The production process encompasses all parts of the process from drilling for fuels to refining or processing to the final product. It also includes storage and disposal of waste. Unless otherwise stated, all accidents are associated with production wells.
Since many accidents involve transport of raw materials, several states included in this list have little or no fossil fuel production.
Useful web sites include:
*Bloomberg Businessweek: [http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2014-03-13/25-years-of-oil-spills Twenty-Five Years of Oil Spills] *The US Chemical Safety Board: [http://www.csb.gov/ CSB Home Page] *Earthjustice: [http://earthjustice.org/features/campaigns/fracking-across-the-united-states Fracking Across The United States] *Fractracker Alliance: [http://www.fractracker.org/2014/05/worker-safety/ Well Worker Safety and Statistics] *Fraccidents [https://www.google.com/maps/d/viewer?ll=40.663973%2C-77.805176&spn=5.832868%2C10.437012&msa=0&z=6&source=embed&ie=UTF8&mid=zaxCy5lyf7w8.ktszQQ3C0jUQ Maps of accidents] *National Response Center [http://www.nrc.uscg.mil/ (oil spill registry)] *[https://earthquake.usgs.gov/research/induced/ Induction-Well-Induced Earthquakes (USGS)] [[File:Gas Well Fire in Greene County PA.png|thumb|right|Gas Well Fire in Greene County PA, 11 Feb. 2014, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]
== Alabama ==
*November 8, 2013 – Pickens County, Crude oil train derails, fire, one person evacuated<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/08/us-crude-train-explosion-idUSBRE9A70Q920131108|title=Train carrying crude oil derails, cars ablaze in Alabama|author=Edward McAllister|date=8 November 2013|work=Reuters|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924190630/http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/08/us-crude-train-explosion-idUSBRE9A70Q920131108|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=}}</ref>
== Alaska ==
*March 24, 1989 – The [[Exxon Valdez oil spill]] occurred in [[Prince William Sound, Alaska]]. *December 31, 2012 – Offshore drilling rig breaks loose from tow, 18 evacuated<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/02/business/energy-environment/breakaway-oil-rig-runs-aground-in-gulf-of-alaska.html|title=Rig Runs Aground in Alaska, Reviving Fears About Arctic Drilling|date=2 January 2013|work=The New York Times|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310124203/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/02/business/energy-environment/breakaway-oil-rig-runs-aground-in-gulf-of-alaska.html|archivedate=10 March 2016|df=}}</ref> *[[2016–2017 Cook Inlet natural gas leak]] *April 14, 2017 - A BP well leaked oil & gas from the North Slope for 3 days.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.alaskapublic.org/2017/04/17/bp-halts-oil-and-gas-leaking-from-north-slope-well/|title=BP halts oil and gas leaking from North Slope well|first=Elizabeth Harball, Alaska's Energy Desk -|last=Anchorage|publisher=}}</ref>
== Arizona ==
*State had active oil and or gas wells as of April 2015 but no accidents have been uncovered.<ref name="nrdc.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.nrdc.org/land/drilling/files/fracking-company-violations-IP.pdf|title=NRDC “Fracking’s Most Wanted, April 2015|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414105051/http://www.nrdc.org/land/drilling/files/fracking-company-violations-IP.pdf|archivedate=2015-04-14|df=}}</ref>
== Arkansas ==
*September 2010 – March 2011 – Near Greenbrier, earthquake swarm near injection wells, largest 4.7<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/15/arkansas-earthquakes-2011-fracking_n_835868.html|title=Arkansas Earthquakes Decline After 'Fracking' Injection Well Closures|date=15 March 2011|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160131143807/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/15/arkansas-earthquakes-2011-fracking_n_835868.html|archivedate=31 January 2016|df=}}</ref> *May 21, 2012 - A fire and explosion broke out at an abandoned crude oil tank battery, near El Dorado.<ref>https://response.epa.gov/site/site_profile.aspx?site_id=7858</ref> *March 29, 2013 – Mayflower – "Exxon-Pegasus" oil pipeline spill, 22 homes evacuated<ref>[[2013 Mayflower oil spill]]</ref> *November 12, 2014 – earthquake, see Kansas
== California ==
*Jan. 27, 1908 - Lightning struck tank number 3 of the Union Oil Co. tank farm at Avila. The bolt struck at 3:30 p.m. and ignited the oil stored in the tank.<ref name="sanluisobispo.com">http://www.sanluisobispo.com/news/local/news-columns-blogs/photos-from-the-vault/article198181544.html</ref> *April 7, 1926 - A lightning-caused fire, involving a 1 million gallon tank, near San Luis Obispo.<ref name="sanluisobispo.com"/> *September 16, 1928 – George F. Getty Inc. well exploded at the Santa Fe Springs oil fields, igniting a fire that burned for almost two months.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/visuals/photography/la-me-fw-archives-santa-fe-springs-oil-well-fires-20170412-story.html|title=From the Archives: Santa Fe Springs oil well fires|first=Scott|last=Harrison|website=latimes.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170506042544/http://www.latimes.com/visuals/photography/la-me-fw-archives-santa-fe-springs-oil-well-fires-20170412-story.html|archivedate=2017-05-06|df=}}</ref> *1969 – The [[1969 Santa Barbara oil spill]]. In January and February 1969, in the Santa Barbara Channel, near the city of Santa Barbara, in Southern California. It was the largest oil spill in United States waters at the time, and now ranks third after the 2010 Deepwater Horizon and 1989 Exxon Valdez spills. It remains the largest oil spill to have occurred in the waters off California. *April 10, 1989 – An explosion and fire occurred in a cracking column at the Chevron Richmond refinery. A total of 8 workers and firefighters were injured. Three workers suffered second and third degree burns. *February 23, 1999 - A fire occurred in the crude unit at Tosco Corporation's Avon oil refinery in Martinez. Workers were attempting to replace piping attached to a 150-foot-tall fractionator tower while the process unit was in operation. During removal of the piping, naphtha was released onto the hot fractionator and ignited. The flames engulfed five workers located at different heights on the tower. Four men were killed, and one sustained serious injuries.<ref>http://www.csb.gov/tosco-avon-refinery-petroleum-naphtha-fire/</ref> *March 25, 1999 – An explosion and fire, at the Chevron Richmond refinery, that spread noxious fumes, and sent hundreds of Richmond residents to hospitals. *August 6, 2012 – A large fire erupted at the Chevron Richmond refinery. About 15,000 sought medical treatment for exposure to the smoke. On April 15, 2013, the US Chemical Safety Board released their preliminary report citing Chevron for a chronic failure to replace aging equipment and called for an overhaul of regulatory oversight of the industry to prevent such accidents from happening again. *February 12, 2014, - Sulfuric acid burned two workers in a Martinez refinery's alkylation unit, who were transported to the nearest hospital burn unit by life flight. The incident occurred when the operators opened a block valve to return an acid sampling system back to service. Very shortly after this block valve had been fully opened, the tubing directly downstream of the valve came apart, spraying two operators with acid.<ref>http://www.csb.gov/tesoro-martinez-sulfuric-acid-spill/</ref> *May 15, 2014 – Los Angeles, pipeline rupture, 4 sickened<ref>"Pipeline breaks, spills crude oil into Los Angeles neighborhood", Reuters, May 15, 2014</ref> *February 18, 2015 – Torrence, refinery explosion, four injured<ref>http://www.csb.gov/exxonmobil-refinery-explosion-/</ref> *May 19, 2015 – Santa Barbara – Pipeline rupture, large oil spill <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-pipeline-santa-barbara-coast-20150519-story.html#page=1|title=105,000 gallons of oil may have spilled in Santa Barbara County|author=Los Angeles Times|date=20 May 2015|work=latimes.com|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126141827/http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-pipeline-santa-barbara-coast-20150519-story.html#page=1|archivedate=26 January 2016|df=}}</ref> *October 22, 2017 - An oil well pump fire, east of Orcutt.<ref>http://santamariatimes.com/news/local/firefighters-extinguish-oil-pump-fire-east-of-orcutt/article_44f14e65-ab80-5998-9265-f1330eb876ee.html</ref> *January 19, 2018 - A fire broke out in the cooling tower of a refinery in Bakersfield.<ref>https://www.yahoo.com/news/crews-battle-fire-oil-refinery-145240059.html</ref>
== Colorado ==
*[http://cogcc.state.co.us/Announcements/Hot_Topics/SpillsAndReleases/SpillAnalysisByYear2014Q3.pdf Oil spill data are available on Colorado Oil and Gas Conservation Commission Spill Analysis website ] *August 2001 through 2012 – [[Trinidad, Colorado|Trinidad]], earthquakes up to magnitude 5.3 <ref>See Wikipedia article [[2011 Colorado earthquake]]</ref> *February 2004 - Williams was fined $30,000 for a fire at a well in Parachute.<ref>https://www.aspentimes.com/news/encana-racks-up-the-fines/</ref> *February 26, 2006 – Fire at a gas compressor station, southwest of [[Fort Lupton, Colorado|Fort Lupton]]<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cardona/Merritt |title=Natural-gas tank ignites |url=https://www.denverpost.com/2006/02/26/natural-gas-tank-ignites/ |website=The Denver Post |accessdate=31 May 2018 |date=26 February 2006}}</ref> * June 25, 2012 - One worker dead, two injured at BP Pinon natural gas compressor station explosion<ref name="PennEnergy June 2012 BP Bayfield explosion">{{cite web |last1=Price |first1=Hilton |title=Worker killed in explosion at BP gas compression station |url=http://www.pennenergy.com/articles/pennenergy/2012/06/worker-killed-in-explosion.html |website=www.pennenergy.com |accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref><ref name="Reuters June 2012 BP Bayfield explosion">{{cite web |last1=Hasterok |first1=Pamela |title=BP investigates fatal Colorado natgas blast |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-explosion-bp/bp-investigates-fatal-colorado-natgas-blast-idUSBRE85P1GE20120626 |website=Reuters |accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref> in [[Bayfield, Colorado|Bayfield]] *September 11, 2012 – A malfunction and fire at a gas compressor station, in Colorado.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/kindermorgan-cig-fire-idINL1E8KC7PZ20120912|title=Colorado Interstate Gas sets force majeure after compressor fire|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170204171800/http://in.reuters.com/article/kindermorgan-cig-fire-idINL1E8KC7PZ20120912|archivedate=2017-02-04|df=}}</ref> *May 9, 2014 – Weld County: six crude oil tankers of 100-car train derail, one leaks an estimated 6,500 gal. (of 28,000 gal. contents)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Environment/Latest-News-Wires/2014/0510/Colorado-derailment-Six-crude-oil-tankers-jump-track|title=Colorado derailment: Six crude oil tankers jump track|author=The Christian Science Monitor|date=10 May 2014|work=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305074618/http://www.csmonitor.com/Environment/Latest-News-Wires/2014/0510/Colorado-derailment-Six-crude-oil-tankers-jump-track|archivedate=5 March 2016|df=}}</ref> *November 13, 2014 – Weld County explosion, one dead, two injured,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/business/ci_26930029/one-dead-following-fracking-accident-weld-county|title=Fracking blast kills one Halliburton worker, injures 2 in Weld County|author=Jesse Paul and Mark Jaffe The Denver Post|date=13 November 2014|publisher=|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201040853/http://www.denverpost.com/business/ci_26930029/one-dead-following-fracking-accident-weld-county|archivedate=1 February 2016|df=}}</ref> *April 17, 2015 - Lightning struck a wastewater storage tank in Greeley, which ignited the vapors inside. Other storage tanks then caught fire.<ref>https://www.greeleytribune.com/news/local/greeley-fire-department-learns-several-lessons-in-its-first-big-test-in-oil-gas-firefighting/</ref> *April 17, 2017 – A severed flow line, from a gas well, leads to a gas explosion in a home, killing 2 people, in [[Firestone, Colorado]].<ref name="CO Independent Anadarko safety May 2018">{{cite web |last1=Greene |first1=Susan |title=Former Anadarko brass slam company for safety risks, callousness |url=http://www.coloradoindependent.com/170106/anadarko-firestone-explosion-safety-lawsuit |website=The Colorado Independent |accessdate=31 May 2018 |date=8 May 2018}}</ref><ref name="Den Post May 2018 Anadarko safety sacrificed for profit">{{cite web |last1=Osher |first1=Christoper N. |title=Former Anadarko employees say safety sacrificed for profits in run up to fatal home explosion in Firestone |url=https://www.denverpost.com/2018/05/08/anadarko-firestone-home-explosion-safety-profits/ |website=The Denver Post |accessdate=31 May 2018 |date=8 May 2018}}</ref> *May 8, 2017 – Fire broke out at a tank for a fracking well near Greeley.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aurorasentinel.com/news/business/worker-seriously-burned-fire-greeley-petroleum-well/|title=Worker seriously burned by fire at Greeley petroleum well - Aurora Sentinel|date=8 May 2017|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171012043604/http://www.aurorasentinel.com/news/business/worker-seriously-burned-fire-greeley-petroleum-well/|archivedate=12 October 2017|df=}}</ref> *May 25, 2017 – An oil tank explosion and fire in northern Colorado killed a worker, and burned three others.<ref name="FOX31 May 2017 Anadarko Weld County explosion">{{cite web |last1=Konopasek |first1=Michael |title=One killed, 3 injured in Anadarko oil tank explosion in Weld County |url=http://kdvr.com/2017/05/25/oil-tank-battery-explosion-fire-in-mead-injures-3/ |website=FOX31 Denver |accessdate=31 May 2018 |date=25 May 2017}}</ref> *September 20, 2017 - A fire at oil tank farm in Weld County.<ref>https://kdvr.com/2017/09/20/no-injuries-reported-at-fire-at-oil-tank-farm-in-weld-county/</ref> *October 29, 2017 - An oil well near [[Berthoud, Colorado|Berthoud]], capped in 1984, began spilling drilling mud.<ref>http://www.reporterherald.com/news/larimer-county/ci_31439372/crews-start-plugging-berthoud-area-oil-well-that</ref> *December 22, 2017 - One person injured in an explosion & fire at an oil well in [[Weld County, Colorado]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kdvr.com/2017/12/22/fire-reported-at-oil-well-site-near-windsor-in-weld-county/|title=Investigation begins into oil site explosion, fire near Windsor|date=23 December 2017|publisher=}}</ref> *February 18, 2018 - A liquid spill near tanks used in oil drilling, near [[Erie, Colorado|Erie]], was more 200 gallons.<ref>https://www.denverpost.com/2018/02/18/hydrocarbon-spill-anadarko-well-site-erie/</ref> *April 19, 2018 - A pipeline released an unknown amount of oil & gas production wastewater, near Bayfield.<ref>https://durangoherald.com/articles/221328</ref> *June 19, 2018 - A lightning strike caused an explosion that damaged or destroyed up to six oil tanks at a storage facility near Hudson in Weld County.<ref>https://kdvr.com/2018/06/19/lightning-strike-causes-explosion-at-weld-county-oil-production-facility/</ref>
== Delaware ==
*July 17, 2001, an explosion occurred at the Motiva Enterprises refinery in Delaware City. A work crew had been repairing a catwalk above a sulfuric acid storage tank farm when a spark from their hot work ignited flammable vapors in one of the tanks. This tank had holes in its roof and shell due to corrosion. The tank collapsed, and one the contract workers was killed; eight others were injured. A significant volume of sulfuric acid was released to the environment.<ref>http://www.csb.gov/motiva-enterprises-sulfuric-acid-tank-explosion/</ref> *November 5, 2005 - Two contract employees were overcome and fatally injured by nitrogen as they performed maintenance work near a 24-inch opening on the top of a reactor. One of the workers died attempting rescue.<ref>http://www.csb.gov/valero-refinery-asphyxiation-incident/</ref> *November 29, 2015 - An operator at the Delaware City Refining Company's (DCRC) Kellogg Alkylation Unit suffered second degree burns to his face and neck areas while performing de-inventorying activities on a vessel in preparation for the removal of a pipe spool from a connected process. This incident follows two other incidents at the same facility which occurred on August 21, and August 28, 2015.<ref>http://www.csb.gov/delaware-city-refining-company/</ref>
== Florida ==
*State had active oil and or gas wells as of April 2015 but no accidents have been uncovered.<ref name="nrdc.org"/>
== Idaho ==
*State had active oil and or gas wells as of April 2015 but no accidents have been uncovered.<ref name="nrdc.org"/>
== Illinois ==
*November 20, 2012 – Mokena, Pipe rupture, oil spill in tank farm<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2012-11-21/bp-chicap-pipe-spilled-oil-at-illinois-tank-farm-filing-shows|title=BP Chicap Pipe Spilled Oil at Illinois Tank Farm, Filing Shows|author=Aaron Clark|date=21 November 2012|work=Bloomberg.com|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303235916/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2012-11-21/bp-chicap-pipe-spilled-oil-at-illinois-tank-farm-filing-shows|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=}}</ref> *March 5, 2015 – Galena, train derailment, fire, evacuations<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/national_world/2015/03/05/oil-train-jumps-tracks-in-illinois.html|title=Oil train jumps tracks in Illinois|author=Edward McAllister|work=The Columbus Dispatch|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201142021/http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/national_world/2015/03/05/oil-train-jumps-tracks-in-illinois.html|archivedate=1 February 2016|df=}}</ref> *November 14, 2017 - A man was seriously hurt in an oil rig explosion & fire in White County, and later died from his injuries.<ref>http://www.14news.com/story/36842703/man-dies-after-white-co-oil-rig-explosion</ref>
== Indiana ==
*About March 26, 2014 – Whiting – Crude oil spill from refinery<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2014-03-28/news/chi-bp-oil-spill-lake-michigan-20140327_1_london-based-oil-company-oil-spill-whiting|title=BP raises estimate of Lake Michigan oil spill|work=tribunedigital-chicagotribune|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304114029/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2014-03-28/news/chi-bp-oil-spill-lake-michigan-20140327_1_london-based-oil-company-oil-spill-whiting|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}}</ref>
== Kansas ==
*June 25, 2013 - An oil tank battery located in Ft. Leavenworth was struck by lightning & burned.<ref>http://www.ftleavenworthlamp.com/article/20130625/blogs/306259999</ref> *September 23, 2014 - A lightning storm caused a Russell Co. tank battery fire.<ref>http://www.hutchpost.com/morning-storm-causes-russell-co-tank-battery-fire/</ref> *November 12, 2014 – Sumner County, epicenter of magnitude 4.8 earthquake<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/11/12/kansas-oklahoma-earthquake/18939417/|title=4.8 quake shakes Kansas, Oklahoma, Arkansas|date=12 November 2014|work=USA TODAY|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110102651/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/11/12/kansas-oklahoma-earthquake/18939417/|archivedate=10 January 2016|df=}}</ref> *January 19, 2015 – see OK *September 25, 2017 - Lightning causes an oil tank battery fire near Lindsborg.<ref>https://www.ksn.com/news/local/lightning-causes-battery-tank-fire-near-lindsborg/898646322</ref> *April 30, 2018 - Lightning is blamed for a pair of oil tank battery fires in Reno and Russell counties.<ref>http://www.kwch.com/content/news/Much-of-Kansas-481326531.html</ref> *June 26, 2018 - A lightning strike was blamed for oil tank fire, southwest of Oxford.<ref>http://www.sumnernewscow.com/lightning-strike-blamed-for-oil-tank-fire-southwest-of-oxford-building-collapses-in-mulvane-caldwell/</ref>
== Kentucky ==
*January, 2005 – Carrolton, Crude oil pipeline rupture, oil spill,<ref name="auto">‘Oil spill at nature preserve "absolutely terrible"', http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/local/2014/03/18/crews-investigate-colerain-gas-leak/6554741/, Cincinnati Enquirer, March 19, 2014</ref> *October, 2008 – Burlington, Crude oil pipeline rupture, oil spill, 80 homes evacuated<ref name="auto"/>
== Louisiana ==
*November 30, 1980 - An oil rig contracted by Texaco accidentally drilled into the Diamond Crystal Salt Company salt mine under the lake. Because of an incorrect or misinterpreted coordinate reference system, the 14-inch (36 cm) drill bit entered the mine, starting a chain of events that turned the lake from freshwater to salt-water, with a deep hole. All 55 employees in the mine at the time of the accident were able to escape thanks to well-planned and rehearsed evacuation drills, while the crew of the drilling rig fled the platform before it was sucked down into the new depths of the lake.<ref>https://www.damninteresting.com/lake-peigneur-the-swirling-vortex-of-doom/</ref> *October 24, 1998 - A catastrophic vessel failure and fire occurred near Pitkin, at the Temple 22-1 Common Point Separation Facility owned by Sonat Exploration Co. Four workers who were near the vessel were killed, and the facility sustained significant damage. The vessel lacked a pressure relief system and ruptured due to overpressurization during start-up, releasing flammable material which ignited.<ref>http://www.csb.gov/sonat-exploration-co-catastrophic-vessel-overpressurization/</ref> *2004 [[Taylor oil spill]] a low-volume on-going event, which as of 2018, was still leaking between 300 and 700 barrels of oil a day.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/a-14-year-long-oil-spill-in-the-gulf-of-mexico-verges-on-becoming-one-of-the-worst-in-us-history/2018/10/20/f9a66fd0-9045-11e8-bcd5-9d911c784c38_story.html?noredirect=on&utm_term=.52f009b46d92|title=A 14-year-long oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico verges on becoming one of the worst in U.S. history|publisher=Washington Post}}</ref> *July 20, 2010 – [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill]], in the Gulf of Mexico, 11 dead *July 22, 2013 – Offshore gas well, 44 workers evacuated<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/national_world/2015/05/16/oil-well-leak-in-gulf-of-mexico-could-go-on-for-100-years-u-s--says.html|title=Oil-well leak in Gulf of Mexico could go on for 100 years, U.S. says|author=Eric Tucker|work=The Columbus Dispatch|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201163527/http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/national_world/2015/05/16/oil-well-leak-in-gulf-of-mexico-could-go-on-for-100-years-u-s--says.html|archivedate=1 February 2016|df=}}</ref> *October 8, 2015 - Three people were killed and two others were seriously wounded Thursday when a natural gas plant in Gibson Louisiana exploded.<ref>http://gephardtdaily.com/national-international/explosion-at-non-operational-natural-gas-plant-kills-3-injures-2-in-louisiana/</ref> *November 22, 2016, - An isobutane release occurred in the sulfuric acid alkylation unit at the ExxonMobil Refinery in Baton Rouge, Louisiana which resulted in four serious injuries to workers and injured two others. The incident occurred during minor maintenance on a flammable isobutane line which failed, releasing isobutane into the unit which ignited.<ref>http://www.csb.gov/exxonmobil-refinery-chemical-release-and-fire/</ref> *April 14, 2017 – Well blowout in [[Red River Parish, Louisiana]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ktbs.com/story/35192640/well-blowout-on-spring-hill-church-road-in-red-river-parish-road-closed-to-traffic|title=Well blowout continues in Red River Parish; road closed to traffic|first=Sierra|last=Pizarro|publisher=}}</ref> *April 18, 2017 – One worker was killed, and, 2 others injured, by a well tank explosion, in [[Mansfield, Louisiana]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/news/2017/04/18/one-dead-well-explosion-mansfield/100631128/|title=Update: Man killed in Mansfield well explosion identified|publisher=}}</ref> *October 15, 2017 - One worker was missing & presumed dead, after a drilling rig explosion & fire on Lake Pontchartrain. 7 other workers were injured.<ref>http://www.wwltv.com/article/news/jpso-to-continue-search-for-missing-oil-platform-worker/289-483610188</ref> *July 29, 2018 - A flare for an ethylene pipeline spread to the tower it was mounted on in Plaquemine.<ref>https://www.theadvocate.com/baton_rouge/news/communities/westside/article_5ad57d02-9355-11e8-aa39-3702ecf6b3ca.html</ref>
== Maryland ==
*State had active oil and or gas wells as of April 2015 but no accidents have been uncovered.<ref name="nrdc.org"/> *On October 6, 1979, LNG vapors at the [[Dominion Cove Point LNG]] facility leaked from a pump, causing an explosion leading to 1 death, 1 critical injury, and, major damage to the facility.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P79_31.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-06-13 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170505134136/https://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P79_31.pdf |archivedate=2017-05-05 |df= }}</ref>

*July 25, 2010 – Near Marshall, massive spill of [[dilbit]] (diluted bitumin) from Canada<ref>see Wikipedia article: [[Kalamazoo River oil spill]]</ref> *September 16, 2014– Benton Harbor, pipeline gas leak, 500 residents evacuated<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/09/17/transcanada-pipeline-benton-harbor_n_5837862.html|title=TransCanada Pipeline Rupture Prompts Evacuation Of Benton Harbor|date=17 September 2014|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140921013637/http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/09/17/transcanada-pipeline-benton-harbor_n_5837862.html|archivedate=21 September 2014|df=}}</ref> *January 3, 2018 - An oil rig caught fire, injuring 1, in Evart.<ref>http://www.9and10news.com/2018/01/03/evart-fire-department-investigating-following-oil-rig-fire/</ref>
== Mississippi == *June 5, 2006 – Raleigh, oil field explosion, three dead, one injured<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.csb.gov/assets/1/19/Partridge_Report1.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-06-22 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923211448/http://www.csb.gov/assets/1/19/Partridge_Report1.pdf |archivedate=2015-09-23 |df= }} U.S. Chemical Safety Board. “Case Study, Hot Work Control And Safe Work Practices At Oil And Gas Production Wells, Partridge-Raleigh Smith County Oilfield” June, 2007</ref> *October 31, 2009 - Two teens were killed on October 31, 2009, when an oil tank located in a clearing in the woods near one of the teens’ homes in Carnes, MS, exploded.<ref>http://www.csb.gov/on-one-year-anniversary-of-fatal-oil-site-accident-in-forrest-county-mississippi-csb-launches-educational-outreach-initiative/</ref> *June 28, 2016 -An Enterprise Gas Processing, LLC natural gas plant in Pascagoula, Mississippi exploded and burned.<ref>https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/Fire-Still-Burning-After-Large-Gas-Plant-Explosion-in-Mississippi.html</ref>
== Missouri == *April 30, 2013 – Ripley County, crude oil spill from pipeline,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/01/exxon-pipeline-spill-idUSL2N0DI14U20130501|title=Exxon says Missouri oil spills from already-ruptured Pegasus line|author=Reuters Editorial|date=1 May 2013|work=Reuters|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924180945/https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/01/exxon-pipeline-spill-idUSL2N0DI14U20130501|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=}}</ref> *November 29, 2013 – An explosion and fire at a natural gas compressor station, near Houstonia.
== Montana == *July 2, 2011 – 10 miles from Billings, pipeline spill, evacuations<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/03/us/03oilspill.html|title=Ruptured Pipeline Spills Oil Into Yellowstone River|date=3 July 2011|work=The New York Times|accessdate=24 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151010045055/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/03/us/03oilspill.html|archivedate=10 October 2015|df=}}</ref> *January 16, 2015 – near Glendive, pipeline rupture <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greatfallstribune.com/story/news/local/2015/01/19/pipeline-breach-spills-oil-yellowstone-river/21966343/|title=Pipeline breach spills oil into Yellowstone River|date=18 January 2015|work=Great Falls Tribune|accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref> *April 27, 2018 - An estimated 25,000 gallons of oil and 3,780,000 gallons of produced water, also known as brine, were released from an oil well on the Ft Peck Reservation.<ref>http://www.glasgowcourier.com/story/2018/05/02/news/90600-barrels-of-contaminant-spilled-from-oil-well/6185.html</ref>

== Oklahoma ==
=== Accidents === *November 17, 2009 – Elk City, Crane failure,<ref>Oil rig accident in Elk City kills 2 Vici men, NewsOK, November 19, 2009</ref> *March 8, 2012 - Lightning caused an oil tank battery fire in southwest Oklahoma City.<ref>https://newsok.com/article/3655697/lightning-causes-oil-tank-battery-fire-in-southwest-oklahoma-city</ref> *April 18, 2013 - A Lightning strike caused a tank battery fire in NE Oklahoma City.<ref>https://www.koco.com/article/lightning-strike-causes-tank-battery-fire/3794514</ref> *December 17, 2014 – Coal County, 2 dead, 3 injured<ref>UPDATE: Two dead after coal County, Oklahoma oil rig fire Friday, Ponca Post, December 19, 2014</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Schmitt|first1=Madeline|title=Two killed in Coal County drilling rig fire|url=http://www.kxii.com/home/headlines/2-Dead--286345921.html|accessdate=25 June 2017|agency=KXII Fox News 12|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706074124/http://www.kxii.com/home/headlines/2-Dead--286345921.html|archivedate=6 July 2015|df=}}</ref> *February 16, 2016 – One person was injured in an explosion, at a Pittsburg County oil field. Fire spread to 3 other wells.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ktul.com/news/local/oil-field-explosion-reported-in-pittsburg-county|title=1 hospitalized after gas well explosion in Pittsburg County|first=Clayton|last=Youngman|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170310220739/http://ktul.com/news/local/oil-field-explosion-reported-in-pittsburg-county|archivedate=2017-03-10|df=}}</ref> *January 22, 2018 - Five workers killed in a gas well explosion near [[Quinton, Oklahoma]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ehstoday.com/safety/chemical-safety-board-investigates-fatal-gas-well-explosion-oklahoma|title=Chemical Safety Board Investigates Fatal Gas Well Explosion in Oklahoma|date=8 February 2018|publisher=}}</ref> deaths due to burns and smoke inhalation.<ref>{{cite web |title=Colorado man, fellow oil rig workers died of burns and smoke inhalation |url=http://www.koaa.com/story/38107533/colorado-man-fellow-oil-rig-workers-died-of-burns-and-smoke-inhalation |publisher=Associated Press |accessdate=31 May 2018 |language=en}}</ref> *May 24, 2018 - A tank battery caught fire in southwest Oklahoma City.<ref>http://www.news9.com/story/38273672/tank-battery-fire-reported-in-sw-okc</ref> *July 16, 2018 - Multiple fire departments responded to a tank battery fire in Pawnee County.<ref>https://ktul.com/news/local/multiple-fire-departments-battle-tank-battery-fire-during-thunderstorm-in-pawnee-county</ref> *July 29, 2018 - A tank battery fire broke out north of Carrier.<ref>https://www.enidnews.com/news/local_news/battery-fire-reported-near-carrier-sunday-morning/article_3b15fb6e-937c-11e8-8c3c-13c3660bb7cc.html</ref>
=== Earthquakes === *[http://earthquakes.ok.gov/what-we-know/earthquake-map/ The state has posted a list, giving date, location, and magnitude of induction-well-caused earthquakes.] *February 16, 2014 – Richter 3.8<ref>"Oklahoma Shakes, Is Fracking to Blame?", Time, February 18, 2014</ref> *November 12, 2014 – Earthquake, see Kansas *January 19, 2015 – Northern Oklahoma<ref>"Earthquakes rumble in southern Kansas, northern Oklahoma", Wichita Eagle, January Q9, 2015</ref> *January 13, 2016 – A fire at a hydrofracking well in [[Grady County, Oklahoma]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kfor.com/2016/01/13/all-lanes-of-traffic-shut-down-due-to-large-oil-rig-fire/|title=Firefighters extinguish damaging Grady Co. fracking fire|date=13 January 2016|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171012043835/http://kfor.com/2016/01/13/all-lanes-of-traffic-shut-down-due-to-large-oil-rig-fire/|archivedate=12 October 2017|df=}}</ref>
== Oregon ==
*State had active oil and or gas wells as of April 2015 <ref name="auto1">NRDC:"Fracking’s Most Wanted", April 2015</ref> but no accidents have been uncovered. – Major crude oil train derailment in Mosier, a small town in the Columbia gorge spilled and burst into flames June 2016. The accident was due to railway dysfunction and bad parts. As of now, groundwater contamination is found at the site impacting wildlife.

== Texas == *April 11, 1965 - A gas well blew out in Parker County, causing a massive fire. Firefighter Red Adair had to be called in to control the well, which was capped on April 17.<ref>http://www.weatherforddemocrat.com/news/local_news/red-adair-once-extinguished-a-raging-gas-well-fire-near/article_7630ce10-def2-542e-bffb-4b0d68eb1ed9.html</ref> *February 2, 1975 - A ruptured pipe connection on a gas well, near Denver City, released hydrogen sulfide (H2S). 8 people were killed while trying to evacuate their nearby home. A worker checking that well about an alarm was also killed.<ref>http://www.lubbockonline.com/local-news/2010-09-15/denver-city-remembers-h2s-tragedy</ref> *October, 1998 – During heavy rainfall, the roof and sides of a Koch 50,000 barrel (2,100,000 gallon) above-ground storage tank buckled, discharging approximate 24,700 gallons of crude oil into Marcelinas Creek, which is a tributary of the [[San Antonio River]]. The spill occurred 1 mile northwest of Falls City, [[Karnes County, Texas]], and entered Marcelinas Creek at flood stage. The spill was generally contained about three miles downstream. The floodwaters transported the oil laterally well beyond the banks of the creek, coating vegetation in these areas with oil as the floodwaters receded. The three miles of creek and adjacent riparian corridor, consisting of mature hardwood trees and improved pasture, provide essential habitat to numerous species of fish, birds, mammals, and reptiles. It took 17 years for the terms of settlement to be reached with regulators.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cerc.usgs.gov/orda_docs/CaseDetails?ID=1089 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-05-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161214143157/https://www.cerc.usgs.gov/orda_docs/CaseDetails?ID=1089 |archivedate=2016-12-14 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://valleycentral.com/news/local/after-17-years-koch-pipeline-company-will-finally-pay-for-south-texas-oil-spill|title=After 17 years, Koch Pipeline Company will finally pay for South Texas oil spill|first=Sinclair Broadcast|last=Group|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160121153741/http://valleycentral.com/news/local/after-17-years-koch-pipeline-company-will-finally-pay-for-south-texas-oil-spill|archivedate=2016-01-21|df=}}</ref> *January 13, 2003, a vapor cloud fire erupted at the BLSR Operating Ltd. oilfield waste disposal facility near Rosharon, south of Houston. Two BLSR employees and one truck driver were fatally burned. Four other workers suffered serious burns, but survived.<ref>http://www.csb.gov/blsr-operating-ltd-vapor-cloud-fire/</ref> *March 23, 2005 – The [[Texas City Refinery explosion]]; 15 dead, 180 injured<ref>U.S. Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board, Refinery Explosion and Fire. Report No. 2005-04-I-TX , March 2007</ref> *February 16, 2007, a propane fire erupted at the Valero McKee Refinery in Sunray, north of Amarillo. Three workers suffered serious burns, and the refinery was forced to shut down. The fire began following a leak in the propane deasphalting unit and spread quickly, in part because of the rapid collapse of a major pipe rack carrying flammable hydrocarbons. Some of the rack's support columns had not been fireproofed.<ref>http://www.csb.gov/valero-refinery-propane-fire/</ref> *April 27, 2008 - A fire broke out at a tank battery in Ward County.<ref>http://www.newswest9.com/story/8235437/tank-battery-fire-leaves-behind-extensive-damage</ref> *May 15, 2009 - An oil tank battery exploded, following a tank battery fire, in Lamesa.<ref>http://www.kcbd.com/story/10367417/oil-tank-battery-explodes-following-a-fire-in-lamesa</ref> *July 19, 2009 - A fire in the alkylation unit at CITGO's Corpus Christi refinery led to a release of hydrofluoric acid (HF). The alkylation unit makes high-octane blending components for gasoline. One worker was critically burned.<ref>http://www.csb.gov/citgo-refinery-hydrofluoric-acid-release-and-fire/</ref> *July 28, 2009 - A tank battery caught fire near West Odessa.<ref>http://www.newswest9.com/story/10808055/investigation-continues-after-tank-battery-fire-in-west-odessa</ref> *August 28, 2012 - A tank battery caught fire, near Brownwood.<ref>https://www.brownwoodnews.com/volunteer-fire-departments-respond-to-oil-tank-battery-fire-early-monday/</ref> *March 28, 2013 - A tank battery caught fire in Martin County.<ref>http://www.newschannel10.com/story/21822469/officials-called-out-to-tank-battery-fire-in-martin-county</ref> *April 5, 2013 – West, blowout, two dead, two injured<ref>"Two Basic Energy Workers Killed After Texas Well Blowout", Bloomberg News, April 8, 2013</ref> *April 19, 2013 – Gas well blowout in [[Denton, Texas]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsgatheringblog.dentonrc.com/2013/05/gas-well-leak-now-called-blowout.html/|title=Denton News, Sports, Entertainment, Business and Weather - Lightning caused a tank battery fire in southeast Russell County.<ref>http://www.krsl.com/local-news/9373-rural-firefighters-respond-to-tank-battery-fire</ref> *May 22, 2018 - A tank battery was destroyed, after it was struck by lightning and ignited near Hallsville.<ref>https://www.news-journal.com/news/police/lightning-strike-ignites-tank-battery-near-hallsville/article_c7c752fa-5e99-11e8-b332-23f9ee5727e2.html</ref> *May 29, 2018 - Lightning caused a tank battery fire northwest of Hays.<ref>https://www.hayspost.com/2018/05/30/lightning-blamed-for-fire-that-claimed-15-tank-batteries-and-caused-multiple-explosions/</ref> *June 8, 2018 - A tank battery fire broke out in Pecos.<ref>http://www.cbs7.com/content/news/Officials-responding-to-water-disposal-plant-fire-in-Pecos--485018511.html</ref> *June 30, 2018 - A fire was reported at a tank battery, in Glasscock County.<ref>https://www.streetinsider.com/Corporate+News/Laredo+Petroleum+%28LPI%29+Provides+Update+on+Fire+Reported+at+Tank+Battery+in+Glasscock+County%2C+Texas/14366003.html</ref> *July 10, 2018 - A tank battery caught fire in Jones County.<ref>https://ktxs.com/news/big-country/tank-battery-in-rural-jones-county-goes-up-in-flames</ref> *July 18, 2018 - An oilfield worker was killed, and another was injured, after a tank battery caught fire off of U.S. Refinery Road near Loving.<ref>https://www.currentargus.com/story/news/local/2018/07/18/one-injured-tank-battery-fire-near-loving/797368002/</ref> *July 23, 2018 - An oil rig caught on fire in Howard County.<ref>http://www.newswest9.com/story/38708392/patterson-uti-drilling-release-statement-on-howard-co-oil-rig-fire</ref> *August 21, 2018 - An oil tank battery in Southeast Atascosa County caught fire.<ref>https://news4sanantonio.com/news/local/firefighters-work-to-knock-down-several-tank-battery-fires-at-atascosa-county-oil-site</ref> *August 28, 2018 - A fire broke out at a Plains All American Pipeline crude storage tank east of Wichita Falls, Texas.<ref>https://uk.reuters.com/article/plains-all-amer-fire-crude/update-3-fire-breaks-out-at-plains-all-american-crude-tank-near-wichita-falls-texas-idUKL2N1VJ0Q2</ref>
== Utah == * March 6, 1935 – Five miles south of St. George, 70 to over 100 local townspeople gathered to watch the shooting of an Arrowhead Petroleum Company's Escalante oil, well unaware of impending danger. The explosion occurred about 9:40 pm while six 10 foot long torpedoes, each loaded with nitroglycerin and TNT and hanging from the derrick, were being lowered into the well. All told, 2,500 pounds of nitroglycerin exploded and sent a shaft of fire into the night that was seen as far as 18 miles away. Ten people lost their lives, and more were injured.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wchsutah.org/miscellaneous/escalante-well-explosion.php|title=Explosion of the Escalante Oil Well|website=wchsutah.org|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170313232400/http://wchsutah.org/miscellaneous/escalante-well-explosion.php|archivedate=2017-03-13|df=}}</ref> * January 14, 2005 - A pipe at the Silver Eagle Refinery in Woods Cross failed, expelling hydrogen and diesel fuel, that caused 30- to 40-foot flames.<ref>https://www.cityweekly.net/utah/utahs-unstable-oil-refineries/Content?oid=2143355&storyPage=2</ref> * January 12, 2009 - 2 refinery operators and 2 contractors suffered serious burns resulting from a flash fire at the Silver Eagle Refinery in Woods Cross. The accident occurred when a large flammable vapor cloud was released from an atmospheric storage tank, known as tank 105, which contained an estimated 440,000 gallons of light naphtha. The vapor cloud found an ignition source and the ensuing flash fire spread up to 230 feet west of the tank farm.<ref name="CSB Silver Eagle report">{{cite web|title=Silver Eagle Refinery Flash Fire and Explosion and Catastrophic Pipe Explosion - Investigations|url=http://www.csb.gov/silver-eagle-refinery-flash-fire-and-explosion-and-catastrophic-pipe-explosion/|publisher=U.S. Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board|accessdate=23 February 2018|language=en}} {{PD-notice}}</ref> * November 4, 2009, a second accident occurred at the Silver Eagle Refinery in Woods Cross, when a powerful blast wave caused by the failure of a 10-inch pipe damaged nearby homes.<ref name="CSB Silver Eagle report"/> * June 10, 2012 – The [[Red Butte Creek oil spill]] in Salt Lake City caused significant pollution. * November 21, 2012 - Two men who suffered burns when a natural gas compressor station exploded in Dry Canyon.<ref>https://www.deseretnews.com/article/865567303/2-injured-in-natural-gas-explosion-remain-hospitalized.html</ref> * January 22, 2013 – A natural gas well fire, in [[Roosevelt, Utah]] forces evacuations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865571178/Natural-gas-well-fire-in-Roosevelt-forces-evacuations.html|title=Natural gas well fire forces evacuations in Roosevelt|first=Geoff|last=Liesik|date=22 January 2013|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171012150118/https://www.deseretnews.com/article/865571178/Natural-gas-well-fire-in-Roosevelt-forces-evacuations.html|archivedate=12 October 2017|df=}}</ref> * January 19, 2018 - A double tanker vehicle hauling gasoline exploded & burned on I-15 in Midvale UT.<ref>https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/utah/articles/2018-01-19/crews-working-to-repair-i-15-after-gas-tanker-explosion</ref> * July 28, 2018 - Two men were "badly burned" and suffered "significant injuries", as a result of an explosion at a natural gas collection facility near Cisco, Utah.<ref>https://www.gjsentinel.com/breaking/explosion-near-gas-plant-in-cisco-utah-seriously-injures-two/article_a7b4c1f4-928e-11e8-8630-2b7b1331a14f.html</ref>
== Virginia == *March 31, 2014 - A large explosion rocked a natural gas processing plant on the Washington-Oregon border, injuring five workers, causing about 400 people to evacuate from nearby farms and homes, and emitting a mushroom cloud of black smoke that was visible for more than a mile. The blast at the Williams Northwest Pipeline facility near the Washington town of Plymouth, along the Columbia River, sparked a fire and punctured one of the facility's two giant storage tanks for liquefied natural gas.<ref>https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/03/31/washington-gas-plant-explosion/7139923/</ref> *April 9, 2014 – Lynchburg, Train derailment, explosion, fire, 300 people evacuated, oil spill<ref>"The Bad Oil Boom: Train Explodes in Virginia Town While Regulators Chug Along" Bloomberg Businessweek, April 30, 2014</ref>
== Washington ==
*April 2, 2010 - An explosion and fire led to the fatal injury of seven employees when a nearly forty-year-old heat exchanger catastrophically failed during a maintenance operation to switch a process stream between two parallel banks of exchangers at the Tesoro refinery in Anacortes.<ref>http://www.csb.gov/tesoro-refinery-fatal-explosion-and-fire/</ref>
== West Virginia ==
*List of spills is posted on [http://www.dep.wv.gov/oil-and-gas/databaseinfo/Pages/OGD.aspx West Virginia Department of Environmental Protection database]. Company name is needed to search database. *June 7, 2010 through January 26, 2015 – Ohio River Valley, Numerous accidents, 2 dead, 7 injured, about 1000 evacuated<ref name="auto2"/> *September 9, 2010 – Explosion and a fire that burned for 9 days, in Wetzel County. *February 5, 2012 – Taylor County, Explosion, One dead<ref>"West Virginia EQT Explosion Kills Worker At Taylor County Natural Gas Well Pad", AP, February 15, 2013</ref> *April 11, 2013 – 2 workers died from injuries sustained in an explosion at a natural gas operation, in Tyler County *July 7, 2013 – Dodridge County, Well fire, Five injured,<ref>"Update: Gas Well Fire Injures 5 Workers in Doddridge County", WBOY.com, July 8, 2013</ref> *February 16, 2015 – Mount Carbon – derailment, one injured, 85 evacuated <ref>"West Virginia oil train derailment: Fires for hours, smoke", Columbus Dispatch, February 17, 2015</ref> *May 25, 2018 - A storage tank exploded at a well site, killing one, and injuring 3 others, in Doddridge County.<ref>http://www.thenewscenter.tv/content/news/Explosion-at-Doddridge-County-well-injures-at-least-4-people-483707971.html</ref> *June 7, 2018 - Seven people were injured in an explosion, at a two-day-old gas well that had recently started drilling to the deep Marcellus shale formation, in Moundsville.<ref>http://www.post-gazette.com/breaking/2010/06/07/7-hurt-in-W-Va-gas-well-explosion/stories/201006070145</ref>
== Wisconsin ==
*July 29, 2012 – Pipeline oil spill, one evacuation<ref>"UPDATE 4-Enbridge to replace leaky Wisconsin oil pipeline Monday", Reuters, July 29, 2012</ref>
== Wyoming == *August 2006 – A fracking well blowout near Clark forced many in 25 nearby homes to evacuate.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://preservethebeartoothfront.com/2014/07/17/a-personal-story-deb-thomas-beartooth-front-wyoming/|title=A personal story: Deb Thomas, Beartooth Front, Wyoming|date=18 July 2014|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125213822/http://preservethebeartoothfront.com/2014/07/17/a-personal-story-deb-thomas-beartooth-front-wyoming/|archivedate=25 November 2015|df=}}</ref> *December 6, 2011 – An explosion at a Falcon natural gas compressor station, south of Pinedale.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://trib.com/news/opinion/blogs/boom/video-falcon-natural-gas-compressor-station-explodes/article_71423ebc-3e26-11e1-aae5-0019bb2963f4.html|title=VIDEO: Falcon natural gas compressor station explodes|first=Jeremy Fugleberg, Casper|last=Star-Tribune|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171012043649/http://trib.com/news/opinion/blogs/boom/video-falcon-natural-gas-compressor-station-explodes/article_71423ebc-3e26-11e1-aae5-0019bb2963f4.html|archivedate=2017-10-12|df=}}</ref> *September 24, 2012 – Well blowout<ref>"Chesapeake Wyoming well blowout no threat to water – EPA" Reuters, April 26, 2012</ref> *December 25, 2013 – An explosion, and flash fire, at a Legacy Resources Natural Gas Compressor Station, injured one man, near Riverton.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.county10.com/2013/12/25/breaking-natural-gas-compressor-fire-injures-one-east-sand-draw-morning/|title=UPDATE: Legacy Resources natural gas compressor explosion injured one at North Alkali Field today – County 10™|website=archive.county10.com}}</ref> *April 23, 2014 - There was an explosion followed by a fire, at the Williams Gas Plant near Opal, Wyo. The entire town of Opal was evacuated after 4 p.m., according to the natural gas company Williams.<ref>https://www.denverpost.com/2014/04/23/wyoming-town-evacuated-after-gas-plant-explosion/</ref> *September 23, 2014 - 4 men had severe burns from an explosion at a gas plant pumping station, near Opal, Wyoming. One man died later on.<ref>https://fox13now.com/2014/09/23/explosion-reported-at-gas-plant-pumping-station-in-wyoming/</ref><ref>http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-worker-dies-from-wyoming-natural-gas-tank-blast-2014sep24-story.html</ref> *March 16, 2018 - Several oil storage tanks were involved in a fire, in southern Campbell County.<ref>https://www.gillettenewsrecord.com/news/local/article_754f4c50-5df6-574a-9e62-1141c60d9a48.html</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Natural gas and oil production accidents in the United States}} [[Category:Petroleum in the United States|Accidents]] [[Category:Natural gas in the United States|Accidents]] [[Category:Water pollution in the United States|Accidents]] [[Category:Energy-related lists]]

page.title: List of planetary features with Māori names

revision.comment: new key for [[Category:Lists of Solar System objects]]: "Maori" using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=June 2013}}
In the [[International Astronomical Union]]'s system of unique feature names for topographic and [[albedo]] features on planets and moons in the [[Solar System]], many are named in [[te reo Māori|the language]] of the indigenous [[Māori people]] of New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web|title=USGS Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/jsp/AllDataPlainText.jsp|publisher=United States Geological Survey|accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> These names are primarily from [[Māori mythology]].
==Venus== Features on the planet [[Venus]] are named for women and goddesses. ''Colles'' are small hills or knobs, named after sea goddesses. ''Coronae'' are oval features of uncertain origin, named for fertility and earth goddesses. ''Planitiae'', low plains, are mythological heroines. ''Tholi'', small dome-like hills, are named for (miscellaneous) goddesses. ''Valles'', valleys, are named according to their length: if more than 400 km, after the word for the planet in various world languages, otherwise after river goddesses.<ref name="categories">{{cite web|title=Categories for Naming Features on Planets and Satellites|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Page/Categories|publisher= Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature, International Astronomical Union (IAU) Working Group for Planetary System Nomenclature (WGPSN)|accessdate=3 September 2010}}</ref><ref name="terms">{{cite web|title=Descriptor Terms (Feature Types)|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/DescriptorTerms|publisher= Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature International Astronomical Union (IAU) Working Group for Planetary System Nomenclature (WGPSN)|accessdate=3 September 2010}}</ref> [[File:NgaManawa.jpg|right|thumb|200px|The hero [[Māui (Māori mythology)|Māui]] stole fire from the fingernails of his grandparent [[Mahuika]].]] *Apakura Tholus: [[Apakura|goddess of justice]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Apakura Tholus|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/313|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref> *Hinemoa Planitia: [[Hinemoa and Tutanekai|heroine]] who swam across [[Lake Rotorua]] to her waiting lover Tutanekai.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hinemoa Planitia|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/2512|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref> *Mahuea Tholus: fire goddess;<ref>{{cite web|title=Mahuea Tholus|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/3593|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref> normally spelt [[Mahuika]]. *Pani Corona: fertility goddess.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pani Corona|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/4578|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref> *Paoro Tholi: [[Paoro|goddess of echoes]]; in the lore of the [[Ngāti Hau]] [[iwi]], she gave voice to the first woman, [[Mārikoriko]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Paoro Tholi|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/4582|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref> *Tawera Vallis: Māori name for Venus,<ref>{{cite web|title=Tawera Vallis|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/5885|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref> though not the more common one. *Urutonga Colles: [[Urutonga|sea goddess]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Urutonga Colles|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/6247|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref> mother of [[Tāwhaki]]. Urutonga is a deity associated with the [[Ngai Tahu]] iwi. *Whatitiri Corona: ancestral goddess;<ref>{{cite web|title=Whatitiri Corona|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/6531|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref> goddess of thunder, also known as [[Whaitiri]].
Craters on Venus that have diameters less than 20 km are named with common female first names:<ref name="categories"/> *Karo crater: first name.<ref>{{cite web|title=Crater, craters: Karo on Venus|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/2930|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref> *Ngaio crater: first name,<ref>{{cite web|title=Ngaio on Venus|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/4239|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref> {{IPAc-en|ˈ|n|aɪ|.|oʊ}}; e.g. writer and theatre director [[Dame Ngaio Marsh]] *Puhioia crater: first name.<ref>{{cite web|title=Puhioia on Venus|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/4865|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref>
==Asteroids== *[[3400 Aotearoa]]: the Māori language name for New Zealand. *[[3810 Aoraki]]: "cloud piercer", after New Zealand's [[Aoraki/Mt Cook|highest mountain]]
===[[433 Eros]]=== *Tutanekai Crater: [[Hinemoa and Tutanekai|Hinemoa]]'s lover in [[Rotorua]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Crater, craters: Tutanekai on Eros|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/6154|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref>
==Io== [[File:Tawhaki Patera.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Highest resolution images of Tawhaki Patera, taken by the [[Galileo (spacecraft)|''Galileo'' spacecraft]]. Color image on the left acquired in July 1999. The gray scale image on the right taken in November 1999.]] The innermost moon of [[Jupiter]], [[Io (moon)|Io]] is a world emblazoned with the reds, yellows, whites and blacks of [[allotropes of sulfur|sulphur chemistry]] and the scars of [[Volcanism on Io|active volcanism]]. Its features have a wide variety of naming themes: gods, goddesses and heroes associated with fire, sun, thunder, and volcanoes; mythical blacksmiths; people associated with the [[Io (mythology)|myth of Io]]; or people from [[Dante's Inferno]]. Names may also be derived from a nearby, more prominent feature; this is a situation where the same name could be used for both a volcano and an adjacent valley.<ref name="categories"/>
''Montes'', mountains, can be named in the Dantean or Greek categories, or for associated features. ''[[Volcanism on Io#Intra-patera eruptions|Paterae]]'', volcanic pits with flat floors and steep walls, are named from these first two groups, and include names from their associated eruptive center. ''Valles'', valleys, are named for their associated feature.<ref name="categories"/><ref name="terms"/> *Rata Mons and Rata Patera: [[Rātā (Māori mythology)|Rātā]], a "sun hero" in the citation, is a grandson of Tāwhaki.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rata Mons|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/4953|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature |accessdate=3 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Rata Patera|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/4954|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature |accessdate=3 September 2010}}</ref> *[[Tawhaki Patera]] and [[Tawhaki Vallis]]: [[Tāwhaki]], "god of lightning" in the citation, is a culture hero sometimes associated with lightning<ref>{{cite web|title=Tawhaki Patera|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/5886|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature |accessdate=3 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tawhaki Vallis|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/5887|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature |accessdate=3 September 2010}}</ref>
==Titan== [[File:PIA10008 Seas and Lakes on Titan.jpg|thumb|right|300px|False-color ''[[Cassini (spacecraft)|Cassini]]'' [[synthetic aperture radar]] mosaic of Titan's north polar region. Blue coloring indicates low radar reflectivity areas, caused by seas of liquid [[ethane]], [[methane]] and dissolved [[nitrogen]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Titan: Exploring an Earthlike World|author=Athéna Coustenis, F. W. Taylor|publisher=World Scientific|year=2008|pages=154–155|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j3O47dxrDAQC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Titan&q=|accessdate=2010-03-25|isbn=978-981-270-501-3}}</ref> [[Punga Mare]] is just above center.]] The largest moon of [[Saturn]] is a world in its own right: [[Titan (moon)|Titan]] has a dense atmosphere and complex weather system, with liquid-carved river networks and sizable seas.
''Maria'', seas, are large expanses of dark materials thought to be liquid hydrocarbons; they are named for sea creatures from myth and literature. ''Virgae'', streaks or stripes of colour, are named for rain gods and goddesses.<ref name="categories"/><ref name="terms"/> *Punga Mare: son of the sea god [[Tangaroa]]; the father of sharks and lizards.<ref>{{cite web|title=Punga Mare|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/14505|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=3 September 2010}}</ref> *Uanui Virgae: rain god; child of the storm god [[Tawhirimatea]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Uanui Virgae|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/14658|work= Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|accessdate=3 September 2010}}</ref>
==Triton== [[Neptune]]'s largest moon is thought to be a captured [[Kuiper belt object]], an interloper from further out in the Solar System. [[Triton (moon)|Triton]]'s features are given aquatic names, excluding Roman and Greek references.<ref name="categories"/> *Tangaroa Crater: [[Tangaroa|god of the sea]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Tangaroa Crater|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/5853|work=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature |accessdate=3 September 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List of planetary features with Maori names}} [[Category:Māori]] [[Category:Māori-related lists]] [[Category:Lists of Solar System objects|Maori]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Syre]] (link changed to [[Syre (river)]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=February 2013}} These are the main rivers of Luxembourg.
All of Luxembourg's rivers are drained into the [[North Sea]], most via the [[Moselle River]], except in the extreme south-west of the country, which are drained by the [[Chiers]]. Rivers that flow into the sea are sorted alphabetically. Rivers that flow into other rivers are sorted by the proximity of their points of confluence to the sea. Some rivers (e.g. [[Meuse]], [[Rhine]]) do not flow through [[Luxembourg]] themselves, but they are mentioned for having tributaries from Luxembourg. They are given in ''italics''. For an alphabetical list of rivers of Luxembourg see [[:Category:Rivers of Luxembourg]].
<!-- Note for additions: Please add the city where the river meets for each river. --> *''[[Meuse River|Meuse]]'' (main branch at [[Goedereede|Stellendam]], [[Netherlands]]) **[[Chiers]] (at [[Bazeilles]], [[France]]) *''[[Rhine]]'' (main branch at [[Hoek van Holland]], [[Netherlands]]) **[[Moselle (river)|Moselle]] (at [[Koblenz]], [[Germany]]) ***[[Sauer]] (at [[Wasserbillig]]) ****[[Black Ernz]] (at [[Grundhof, Luxembourg|Grundhof]]) ****[[White Ernz]] (at [[Reisdorf]]) ****[[Our (river)|Our]] (at [[Wallendorf (Eifel)|Wallendorf]]) ****[[Blees]] (at [[Bettendorf, Luxembourg|Bettendorf]]) ****[[Alzette]] (at [[Ettelbruck]]) *****[[Wark (river)|Wark]] (at [[Ettelbruck]]) *****[[Attert (river)|Attert]] (at [[Colmar-Berg]]) *****[[Eisch]] (at [[Mersch]]) *****[[Mamer (river)|Mamer]] (at [[Mersch]]) *****[[Pétrusse]] (at [[Luxembourg City]]) *****[[Mess (river)|Mess]] (at [[Bergem]]) ****[[Wiltz (river)|Wiltz]] (at [[Goebelsmuhle]]) *****[[Clerve]] (at [[Kautenbach]]) ***[[Syre (river)|Syre]] (at [[Mertert]]) ***[[Gander (Moselle)|Gander]] (in [[Haute-Kontz]], [[France]])
{{List of rivers of Europe}}
[[Category:Rivers of Luxembourg|*]] [[Category:Lists of rivers by country|Luxembourg]] [[Category:Lists of landforms of Luxembourg|Rivers]]

Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Rann of Kutch|Great Rann of Kutch}}[[Image:Map GujDist Kuchchh.png|thumb|right|300px|Map of [[Gujarat]] showing the Little Rann of Kutch and Great Rann of Kutch]] [[File:Asiatic Wild ass.jpg|thumb]] '''Little desert of Kutch'''<ref>[http://www.indianexpress.com/news/needed-in-the-little-rann-of-kutch-a-marketing-strategy-worth-its-salt-to-help-the-agariyas/489339/0 Needed in the Little Rann of Kutch, a marketing strategy worth its salt to help the Agariyas] (2 page article online); by Adam Halliday; Jul 15, 2009; Indian Express Newspaper</ref><ref>[http://www.indianexpress.com/news/rti-revelation-govt-has-no-data-on-little-r/418466/ RTI revelation: govt has no data on Little Rann of Kutch] (2 page article online); by Kamran Sulaimani; Feb 03, 2009; Indian Express Newspaper</ref> is a [[salt marsh]] which is part of [[Rann of Kutch]] in [[Kutch district]], [[Gujarat]], India. [[File:Little Rann of Kutch West Part 1896.jpg|thumb|Little Rann of Kutch West Part 1896]][[File:Little Rann of Kutch East Part 1896.jpg|thumb|Little Rann of Kutch East Part 1896]] ==Indian Wild Ass Sanctuary== [[File:IndianWildAss1.jpg|thumb|Indian wild ass herd in Little Rann of Kutch]] [[File:Flamingo LRK IMG 20161211 123643.jpg|thumb|Flock of Lesser Flamingo in Little Rann of Kutch]] It is famous as the world's last refuge of the [[Indian wild ass]] (khur) for the conservation of which it has been declared as the [[Indian Wild Ass Sanctuary]]. Though a bleak landscape it is rich in biodiversity and is an ecologically important area for wildlife and many local and migratory waterbirds like cranes, ducks, pelicans, flamingos and land birds like sandgrouse, francolins and the Indian bustards.It is also home to various unique mammals apart from wild ass such as the [[Indian wolf]] (''Canis lupus pallipes''), [[White-footed fox|desert fox]] (''Vulpes vulpes pusilla'') and [[nilgai]] (''Boselaphus tragocamelus'').
==Biosphere reserve - world heritage site== It is nominated by the forest department to be a [[biosphere reserve]] which are areas of terrestrial and coastal ecosystems internationally recognized within the framework of UNESCO's Man and Biosphere (MAB) programme. it will focus on conserving biological diversity, research, monitoring and providing sustainable development models, the proposal has been sent to and listed at UNESCO.<ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/2105/ Nomination entry - UNESCO World Heritage Centre]</ref><ref>[http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/Earth/Flora--Fauna/Kutch-gets-biosphere-reserve-status/articleshow/3261967.cms Kutch gets biosphere reserve status - The Greater and Little Rann of Kutch have finally got the much-awaited status of biosphere reserve.]</ref><ref>[http://www.indianexpress.com/news/kutchs-wild-ass-habitat-may-soon-get-herita/206928/ Kutch’s wild ass habitat may soon get heritage label] (2 Page article online); by DP Bhattacharya; Jul 26, 2007; Indian Express Newspaper</ref>
==Economy == [[File:Salt Well Kutch Gujarat India 1891.jpg|thumb|Salt well in Kutch in 1891]] ===Salt panning=== [[File:Salt pane worker Chandra (16474712257).jpg|thumb|Salt pane worker|left]] There is traditional commercial [[salt panning]]<ref>[http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest%2BNews/Asia/Story/A1Story20091116-180178.html The salt-panners of the little Rann]; kuensel online; Nov 16, 2009; asiaone news; Singapore Press Holdings</ref> activity in the region which the state of Gujarat's Forest Department wants to discourage as it is considered a threat to ecology of the region, wildlife and to the endangered Indian wild ass.
===Shrimp farming=== The area is also being used to farm shrimp which is more profitable then salt panning, again this activity is discouraged by the forest department.
===Damming Rann of Kutch=== Gujarat government is studying to dam the 1.26 km stretch of Hadakiya Creek of Rann of Kutch area so that impounded monsoon water is used for recreational and fisheries purposes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Eye on 2019 polls? Tycoon discusses with Modi, Amit Shah Asia's biggest Rann Sarovar sweet water lake in Gujarat|url=https://www.counterview.net/2018/05/eye-on-2019-polls-tycoon-discusses-with.html|accessdate=9 June 2018}}</ref>
==Wildlife sanctuaries and reserves of Kutch== From the city of [[Bhuj]] various [[ecology|ecologically]] rich and [[wildlife conservation]] areas of the Kutch / [[Kachchh district]] can be visited such as [[Indian Wild Ass Sanctuary]], [[Kutch Desert Wildlife Sanctuary]], [[Narayan Sarovar Sanctuary]], [[Kutch Bustard Sanctuary]], [[Banni Grasslands Reserve]] and [[Chari-Dhand Wetland Conservation Reserve]] etc.
==See also== * [[Arid Forest Research Institute]] (AFRI) * [[Great Rann of Kutch]] * [[Indian wild ass]] * [[Kutch District]]
==References== {{reflist}} * {{WWF ecoregion|name=Rann of Kutch seasonal salt marsh |id=im0901}} This text was originally published in the book Terrestrial ecoregions of the Indo-Pacific: a conservation assessment from Island Press. Also see: {{NatGeo ecoregion|id=im0901|name=Rann of Kutch seasonal salt marsh}}

But Gujarat’s politicians have done little for the Agariya community that produces it.]; by Manas Dasgupta; Apr 23, 2009; The Hindu, Online edition of India's National Newspaper *[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-04-11/ahmedabad/28050560_1_nal-sarovar-first-census-wild-asses Wild asses population rises by 4%]; TNN; 11 April 2009; Times of India *[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-04-09/ahmedabad/28034743_1_equine-flu-forest-officials-virus Wild Ass vulnerable to flu]; by TNN; 9 April 2009; Times of India *[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-03-31/rajkot/28028104_1_census-teams-wild-boar-sanctuary Wild ass census to kick off from April 5]; TNN; 31 March 2009; Times of India *[http://www.commodityonline.com/news/Bleak-future-for-traditional-salt-15393-3-1.html Bleak future for traditional salt]; by Anosh Malekar; February 21, 2009; Courtesy : Infochange News & Features; ComodittyOnline *[http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/Earth/Flora--Fauna/Kutch-gets-biosphere-reserve-status/articleshow/3261967.cms Kutch gets biosphere reserve status - The Greater and Little Rann of Kutch have finally got the much-awaited status of biosphere reserve.]; Himanshu Kaushik, TNN; 22 Jul 2008; Economic Times; Times of India *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121002221224/http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/agariyas-wait-for-land-rights-continues-even-after-intervention-by-cmo/286054/ Agariyas’ wait for land rights continues even after intervention by CMO]; Express news service; Mar 19, 2008; Indian Express Newspaper *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121002221047/http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/kutch-branch-canal-through-sanctuary-not-to-hamper-movement-of-wild-ass/273609/ Kutch Branch Canal through sanctuary not to hamper movement of wild ass]; BASHIR PATHAN; Feb 16, 2008; Indian Express Newspaper *[http://www.indianexpress.com/news/kutchs-wild-ass-habitat-may-soon-get-herita/206928/ Kutch’s wild ass habitat may soon get heritage label] (2 Page article online); by DP Bhattacharya; Jul 26, 2007; Indian Express Newspaper *[http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2007/04/09/stories/2007040902591500.htm Salt-makers in Gujarat face eviction]; by Virendra Pandit; Apr 09, 2007; Business Line, Business Daily from THE HINDU group of publications *[http://www.rediff.com/news/2007/feb/15rann.htm Wild ass robs agarias' livelihood]; February 15, 2007; Rediff India Abroad *[http://www.hindu.com/mp/2006/03/04/stories/2006030400320200.htm Indian Wild Ass Sanctuary]; SANCTUARY SPOTLIGHT; Mar 04, 2006; The Hindu, Online edition of India's National Newspaper. Also posted at [http://www.hindu.com/mp/2006/02/27/stories/2006022700320300.htm] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130509024619/http://cities.expressindia.com/fullstory.php?newsid=67090 Japanese duo does donkey work in Rann - ‘‘The female donkeys are left by the maldhari’s on the island of Plaswa village in the Rann of Kutch for about three months during the monsoon. Here, the Wild Ass, a protected species, breed with the female donkeys leading to the birth of hybrid donkeys which are taller than their mothers and wilder than their fathers,’’ says Dr R Kimura who has been a visiting researcher at the Equine Museum of Japan for the past two decades.]; by Rupam Jain; November 3, 2003; Indian Express Newspaper. Also see [http://www.indianexpress.com/oldStory/34794/] *[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2003-11-28/ahmedabad/27185200_1_census-staff-lone-sanctuary-officials-gear Officials gear up for wild ass census]; by TNN; 28 November 2003; Times of India *[http://www.indianexpress.com/res/web/pIe/ie/daily/19990308/ige08141.html Wild ass being robbed of its run of the Little Rann]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}; by ANAND SUNDAS; March 8, 1999; Indian Express Newspaper *[http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?205158 Salt In The Wounds - Gandhi's historic Dandi march has bypassed them. Gujarat's salt workers are caught up in a maze of abysmal living conditions, ignorance and neglect.] By SAIRA MENEZES; Mar 02, 1998;Outlook India Magazine
