revision.comment: cat
revision.text:
'''Rosenfeld's law''' is an axiom relating [[physics]] to [[economics]], that states that the amount of energy required to produce one dollar of [[GDP]] has decreased by about one percent per year since 1845. The original quote by [[Arthur H. Rosenfeld]] is:
From 1845 to the present, the amount of energy required to produce the same amount of gross national product has steadily decreased at the rate of about 1 percent per year. This is not quite as spectacular as [[Moore's Law]] of integrated circuits, but it has been tested over a longer period of time. One percent per year yields a factor of 2.7 when compounded over 100 years. It took 56 [[BTU]]s (59,000 joules) of energy consumption to produce one (1992) dollar of GDP in 1845. By 1998, the same dollar required only 12.5 BTUs (13,200 joules).A.H.Rosenfeld, T. M. Kaarsberg, J. J. Romm, "Efficiency of Energy Use", in The Macmillan Encyclopedia of Energy, John Zumerchik, editor in chief, Macmillan Reference USA, 2001
==Notes== [[Category:Economic indicators]] [[Category:Economics laws]] [[Category:Energy economics]] {{Econ-stub}}

revision.comment: correct spelling; add "Don", name commonly known by
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Roy Gordon (Don) Grainger | image = <!--(filename only)--> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1962|02|19|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Thames, New Zealand|Thames]], New Zealand | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | residence = | citizenship = | fields = [[Remote Sensing]], [[Atmospheric Physics]] | workplaces = [[University of Oxford]], [[St Hugh's College]] | alma_mater = [[University of Auckland]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = Aerosol and Cloud Remote Sensing | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | footnotes = | spouse = }} '''Roy Gordon Grainger''' (born 19 February 1962) is a New Zealand physicist. He is head of the Earth Observation Data Group<ref>[http://eodg.atm.ox.ac.uk/] Earth Observation Data Group website</ref> in the Atmospheric, Oceanic and Planetary Physics Sub-Department at the [[University of Oxford]] and a Tutorial Fellow in [[Physics]] at [[St Hugh's College, Oxford]].<ref>[http://www.st-hughs.ox.ac.uk/people/professor-don-grainger/ Roy Grainger's profile at St Hugh's]</ref>
==Education== Grainger was educated at [[Auckland Grammar School]] before attending the [[University of Auckland]] to read physics. He gained a [[Doctorate]] in [[Atmospheric Physics]] on the subject of remote sensing of cloud properties. He worked for a short time in UV research at the New Zealand Meteorological Service before taking up a post-doctoral position in the Physics Department in Oxford, where his research was focused on measurement of stratospheric aerosols using the ISAMS satellite instrument designed at Oxford.<ref>http://www.st-hughs.ox.ac.uk/people/professor-don-grainger/ Roy Grainger's profile at St Hugh's</ref>
In 1998, he returned to New Zealand to accept a Lectureship at the [[University of Canterbury]], where he conducted new instrumental work to measure aerosol properties.
==Research== Grainger is the Principal Investigator of the Optimal Retrieval of Aerosol and Cloud (ORAC) project,<ref>http://proj.badc.rl.ac.uk/orac/wiki/WikiStart ORAC Website</ref> which is a community code to optimally estimate aerosol and cloud properties from satellite imagery, and was principally responsible for starting this project.
The Earth Observation Data Group which he heads is primarily interested in atmospheric trace gases and clouds (especially with regard to processes which control climate), and conducts satellite studies of atmospheric aerosols.
==Personal life== Grainger lives in [[Oxford]], England, and is the great-grandson of Alfred Henry Grainger, after whom [[Grainger Falls]] is named.
==External links== *[http://www.st-hughs.ox.ac.uk/people/professor-don-grainger/] Homepage at St Hugh's College, University of Oxford *[http://eodg.atm.ox.ac.uk/user/grainger/] Homepage at the Atmospheric Physics Department, Oxford
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Grainger, Roy Gordon}} [[Category:Atmospheric scientists]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Oxford]] [[Category:Fellows of St Hugh's College, Oxford]] [[Category:New Zealand scientists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:People educated at Auckland Grammar School]] [[Category:University of Auckland alumni]] [[Category:University of Canterbury faculty]] [[Category:People from Thames, New Zealand]]

revision.comment: rmv duplicate parms
revision.text:
[[File:Studless_tire_2.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Winter tire, showing tread pattern designed to compact snow in the gaps.<ref> {{cite book | last = Heißing | first = Bernd | last2 = Ersoy | first2 = Metin | author-link = | title = Chassis Handbook: Fundamentals, Driving Dynamics, Components, Mechatronics, Perspectives | publisher = Springer Science & Business Media | date = 2010 | location = | pages = 591 | language = | url = https://books.google.com/?id=NSlSJtEy-NIC&pg=PA53&dq=Tire+siping#v=onepage&q=siping&f=false | isbn = 9783834897893 }}</ref>]] {{Main|Tire}} '''Snow tires'''—also called '''winter tires'''—are [[tire]]s designed for use on [[snow]] and [[ice]]. Snow tires have a [[tread]] design with larger gaps than those on summer tires, increasing [[Traction (engineering)|traction]] on snow and ice. Such tires that have passed a specific winter traction performance test are entitled to display a "Three-Peak Mountain Snow Flake" symbol on their sidewalls. Tires designed for winter conditions are optimized to drive at temperatures below {{convert|7|°C}}. Some snow tires have metal or ceramic studs that protrude from the tire to increase traction on hard-packed snow or ice. Studs abrade dry pavement, causing dust and creating wear in the wheel path.<ref>{{cite web|title=Prall Tester - Studded Tyre Wear Test|url=http://cooper.co.uk/shop/asphalt-testing/prall-tester/|website=www.cooper.co.uk|publisher=[[Cooper Research Technology]] Ltd.|accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref> Regulations that require the use of snow tires or permit the use of studs vary by country in Asia and Europe, and by state or province in North America.
Related to snow tires are those with an [[Tire#All season|M+S rating]], which denotes an "all-season" capability—quieter on clear roads, but less capable on snow or ice than a winter tire.<ref> {{cite book | last = Newton | first = Richard | author-link = | title = Wheel and Tire Performance Handbook | publisher = MotorBooks International | date = 2007 | location = St. Paul | page = 35 | language = | url = https://books.google.com/?id=9EV9-xiiJzcC&pg=PA35&dq=m%2Bs+tire+rating#v=onepage&q=m%2Bs%20tire%20rating&f=false | isbn = 9781610592512 }}</ref>
==Roadway conditions in winter== Snow tires operate on a variety of surfaces, including pavement (wet or dry), mud, ice, or snow. The tread design of snow tires is adapted primarily to allow penetration of the snow into the tread, where it compacts and provides resistance against slippage.<ref> {{Citation | last = Taylor | first = Rich | title = How to pick the right winter tires | journal = Popular Mechanics | pages = 72–78 | date = January 1985 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=_OMDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA74&dq=snow+tire+traction#v=onepage&q=snow%20tire%20traction&f=false }}</ref> The snow strength developed by compaction depends on the properties of the snow, which depend on its temperature and water content—wetter, warmer snow compacts better than dry, colder snow up to a point where the snow is so wet that it lubricates the tire-road interface. New and powder snow have densities of {{convert|0.1 to 0.3|g/cm3|lb/ft3|abbr=on|sigfig=1}}. Compacted snow may have densities of {{convert|0.45 to 0.75|g/cm3|lb/ft3|abbr=on|sigfig=2}}.<ref name = Hays/>
Snow or ice-covered roadways present lower braking and cornering friction, compared to dry conditions. The roadway friction properties of snow, in particular, are a function of temperature. At temperatures below {{convert|20|F|C|order=flip}}, snow crystals are harder and generate more friction as a tire passes over them than at warmer conditions with snow or ice on the road surface. However, as temperatures rise above {{convert|28|F|C|order=flip}}, the presence of free water increasingly lubricates the snow or ice and diminishes tire friction. Hydrophilic rubber compounds help create friction in the presence of water or ice.<ref name=Bard> {{Citation | last = Glenne | first = Bard | title = All about Snow Tires | journal = Skiing | volume = | issue = | pages = 52–55, 272 | date = December 1989 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=3QyZyX1qsEQC&pg=PA52&dq=snow+tire+traction+cornering+braking#v=onepage&q=snow%20tire%20traction%20cornering%20braking&f=false }}</ref>
<center> ;Dry and moist snow conditions on roadways </center> <gallery mode="packed" heights="220px"> File:Mercedes-Benz S203 Yyteri.JPG|Vehicle in cold, dry, powder snow, which offers comparatively better traction than moist snow. File:Саратов пробка у Детского парка.jpg|Vehicles in warm, moist, granular snow encounter decreased roadway traction. </gallery>
==Treads== [[File:Spikereifen.JPG|thumb|Snow tire with metal studs, which improve traction on icy surfaces.]] {{Main|Tire#Components}} Attributes that can distinguish snow tires from "all-season" and summer tires include:<ref name=Bard/> *An open, deep tread, whose ''void ratio'' between rubber and spaces between the solid rubber is comparatively high *''Shoulder blocks''—specialized tread design at the outside of the tire tread to increase snow contact and friction *A narrower ''aspect ratio'' between the diameter of the tire and the tread width to minimize resistance from the plowing effect of the tire through deeper snow *[[Hydrophilic]] rubber compounds that improve friction on wet surfaces Snow tires are designed to encounter many of the same conditions that summer tires encounter, as well, so they incorporate [[Siping (rubber)|siping]] for wet surfaces. Wet-film conditions on hard-compacted snow or ice require studs or chains.<ref name=Bard/>
===Studs=== Many jurisdictions in Asia, Europe, and North America seasonally allow snow tires with metal or ceramic studs to improve grip on packed snow or ice. Such tires are prohibited in other jurisdictions or during warmer months because of the damage they may cause to road surfaces.<ref name="ScienceDaily">{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/01/110105121137.htm|title=How Studded Winter Tires May Damage Public Health, as Well as Pavement|last=ScienceDaily|date=6 January 2011|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> The metal studs are fabricated by encapsulating a hard pin in a softer material base, sometimes called the ''jacket''. The pin is often made of [[tungsten carbide]], a very [[Mohs scale of mineral hardness|hard]] high performance ceramic. The softer base is the part that anchors the stud in the rubber of the tire. As the tire wears with use, the softer base wears so that its surface is at about the same level as the rubber, whereas the hard pin wears so that it continues to protrude from the tire. The pin should protrude at least {{convert|1|mm|in|sigfig=1}} for the tire to function properly.<ref>{{citation|last=Nordström|first=Olle|title=Nya och begagnade vinterdäcks isfriktion: sammanfattningsrapport : undersökning avseende inverkan av ålder, mönsterdjup, slitbanehårdhet, dubbutstick och dubbkraft|date=2004|issn=0347-6049|publisher=Väg-och transportforskningsinstitutet|language=sv | journal =VTI meddelande | issue =966}}</ref> Snow tires do not eliminate skidding on ice and snow, but they greatly reduce risks.<ref>{{citation|title=Effekter av vinterdäck - en kunskapsöversikt|date=2006|publisher=Väg-och transportforskningsinstitutet|author=Gustafsson, M.|display-authors=etal | issue =VTI rapport 543}}</ref>
Studdable tires are manufactured with molded holes on the rubber tire [[tread]]. Usually, there are 80 to 100 molded holes per tire for stud insertion. The insertion is done by using a special tool that spreads the rubber hole so that a stud jacket can be inserted and the [[flange]] at the bottom of the jacket can be fitted nicely to the bottom of the hole. The metal studs come in specific heights to match the depths of the holes molded into the tire tread based on the tread depths. For this reason, stud metals can only be inserted when the tires have not been driven on. A proper stud insertion results in the metal jacket that is flush with the surface of the tire tread having only the pin part that protrudes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Studded Tires for Winter Driving|url=http://www.tirerack.com/winter/tech/techpage.jsp?techid=151|website=Tirerack.com|accessdate=24 January 2015}}</ref>
When studs come into contact with pavements they abrade the asphalt or concrete surface. This can result in creating polluting dust and wear in the wheel path that prevents proper drainage. For this reason, studded tires are banned, at least seasonally, in many jurisdictions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Studded Tyre Wear Test|url=http://cooper.co.uk/shop/asphalt-testing/prall-tester/|website=www.cooper.co.uk|publisher=[[Cooper Research Technology]] Limited|accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref>
==Tire–snow interactions==
The compacted snow develops strength against slippage along a shear plane parallel to the contact area of the tire on the ground. At the same time, the bottom of the tire treads compress the snow on which they are bearing, also creating friction. The process of compacting snow within the treads requires it to be expelled in time for the tread to compact snow anew on the next rotation. The compaction/contact process works both in the direction of travel for propulsion and braking, but also laterally for cornering.<ref name = Hays/>
The deeper the snow that the tire rolls through, the higher the resistance encountered by the tire, as it compacts the snow it encounters and plows some of it to either side. At some point on a given angle of uphill pitch, this resistance becomes greater than the resistance to slippage achieved by the tread's contact with the snow and the tires with power begin to slip and spin. Deeper snow means that climbing a hill without spinning the powered wheels becomes more difficult. However, the plowing/compaction effect aids in braking to the extent that it creates rolling resistance.<ref name = Hays> {{cite book | last = Hays | first = Donald | author-link = | title = The Physics of Tire Traction: Theory and Experiment | publisher = Springer Science & Business Media | date = 2013 | location = | pages = 428 | language = | url = https://books.google.com/?id=rEL2BwAAQBAJ&pg=PA107&lpg=PA107&dq=shear+strength+snow+tire#v=onepage&q=shear%20strength%20snow%20tire&f=false | access-date = 2016-12-25 | isbn = 9781475713701 }}</ref> <center> ;Tire-snow interactions </center> <gallery mode="packed" heights="220px"> File:Snow tire compacting snow ahead of it.jpg|Compaction of snow under an advancing snow tire, causing rolling resistance while passing through about {{convert|10|cm|in|sigfig=1}} of snow. File:Impression left by snow tire rolling through snow.jpg|Compaction in about {{convert|5|cm|in|sigfig=1}} of snow left behind a snow tire, showing tread-snow interaction. </gallery>
==Regulations== [[File:Winter tires with North American symbol.jpg|thumb|Tire showing the ASTM ''3PMSF'' (Three-Peak Mountain Snow Flake) symbol, denoting a qualifying snow tire, and a separate snow flake symbol, that recommends tire replacement with {{convert|4|mm|in}} of tread remaining<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.stuttgart.army.mil/pdf/WinterTires.pdf | title = Winter Tire Rules | last = US Army | first = Stuttgart | date = | website = stuttgart.army.mil | publisher = US Army | access-date = 2017-03-29 | quote = }}</ref>]] [[ASTM International]] (American Society for Testing and Materials International) is an international [[standards organization]] that develops and publishes voluntary consensus technical [[International standard|standard]]s for a wide range of materials, products, systems, and [[Service (economics)|services]]. The pertinent standard for snow tires is ASTM F1805 – 16, ''Standard Test Method for Single Wheel Driving Traction in a Straight Line on Snow- and Ice-Covered Surfaces'', which assess tire performance on snow and ice. It measures the traction of tires under acceleration in the rolling direction.<ref> {{cite journal | last = Subcommittee: F09.20 | title = ASTM F1805 – 16: Standard Test Method for Single Wheel Driving Traction in a Straight Line on Snow- and Ice-Covered Surfaces | journal = ASTM Book of Standards | volume = 9.02 | issue = | pages = 14 | publisher = ASTM International | location = West Conshohocken, PA | date = 2016 | language = | url = https://www.astm.org/Standards/F1805.htm | doi = 10.1520/F1805-16 | access-date = 2017-03-26}}</ref> Tires that pass this test are entitled to display the ''3PMSF'' (Three-Peak Mountain Snow Flake) symbol.<ref> {{cite book | last = Department of Transportation | author-link = U.S. Department of Transportation | title = §571.139 Standard 139 – New pneumatic radial tires for light vehicles | publisher = Office of Federal Register | volume = Title 49 | date = 2007 | location = Washington, DC | page = 505 | language = | url = https://books.google.com/?id=HDHiVcariZQC&pg=PA505&dq=Three-Peak+Mountain+Snowflake+snow+tire+standards#v=onepage&q=Three-Peak%20Mountain%20Snowflake%20snow%20tire%20standards&f=false | isbn = 9781577857778 }}</ref>
===Asia=== In Russia light vehicles and buses must be equipped with snow M+S or ''3PMSF'' tires on all axles from December through February and have a minimum tread depth of {{convert|4|mm|sigfig=1}}.<ref name = Continental> {{cite web | url = http://www.continental-tires.com/transport/knowhow/european-winter-regulations | title = Winter Regulations—European regulations for winter equipment on trucks and buses | last = Editors | first = | date = 2016 | website = continental-tires.com | publisher = Continental Tires | access-date = 2017-03-26 | quote = }}</ref>
All [[prefectures of Japan]], except for the southernmost prefecture of [[Okinawa Prefecture|Okinawa]], require the motorized vehicles to be fitted with winter tires or tire chains if the road is icy or slushy.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://blog.remington1816.com/snow-tires-on-your-car-not-just-a-necessity-but-sometimes-a-law/ | title = Snow Tires on Your Car: Not Just a Necessity But Sometimes a Law | last = Editors | first = | date = January 16, 2015 | website = 1816 – The Magazine | publisher = Remington | access-date = | quote = }}</ref> If tread grooves of snow tires are worn off for more than 50% of its original depth, tires must be replaced to meet the legal requirements. Drivers will be fined for failing to comply with the snow tire or tire chains requirements. Nationwide studded tire restrictions for passenger vehicles came in effect in April 1991, followed by restrictions for commercial trucks in 1993.<ref name="stud.jp.law">{{cite web | url = https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=ja&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Flaw.e-gov.go.jp%2Fhtmldata%2FH02%2FH02HO055.html&edit-text= | title = The Act on Prevention of the Generation of Spike Tire Dust (Act No. 55) | last = e-Gov Laws and Regulations Database | first = | date = June 27, 1990 | website = law.e-gov.go.jp/htmldata/H02/H02HO055.html | publisher = Government of Japan | access-date = | quote = }}</ref> Studded tires are technically still legal in Japan, but the usage is restricted by environmental law and it is a criminal offence to operate a vehicle fitted with studded tire on dry asphalt or concrete.<ref name="stud.jp.law" />
===Europe=== [[File:CZ-C15a Zimní výbava.png|thumb|A Czech Republic road sign ''Winter equipment,'' which mandates the use of snow tires in the winter]] As of 2016, European regulations pertaining to snow tires varied by country. The principal aspects of regulations were whether use was mandatory and whether studded tires were permitted.<ref name = Continental/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.uniroyal-tyres.com/car/tyre-guide/winter-care/winter-tyres-mandatory|title=Winter tyres legislation in Europe - An overview of the regulations {{!}} Uniroyal|website=www.uniroyal-tyres.com|language=en|access-date=2018-07-23}}</ref> [[File:Venäläinen nastarenkaasta varoittava merkki auton perässä..jpg|thumb|Studded tires warning sticker in Russia.]] *''Mandatory use'' – The following countries ''required'' snow tires ''between specified dates'': Austria, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Latvia, Lithuania, Montenegro, Norway, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Sweden, and Russia. *''Studded tires banned'' – The following countries ''banned'' the use of studded tires: Albania, Belgium, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Germany, Hungary, Luxembourg, Macedonia, Montenegro, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Serbia, Slovakia, and Slovenia. *''Studded tires restricted'' – The following allowed the seasonally ''restricted'' use of studded tires: Austria, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Great Britain, Iceland,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dollar.is/winter-driving-in-iceland-winter-tyres/|title=Winter driving in Iceland on winter tyres|last=Brimborg ehf.|first=|date=2017-12-10|website=Dollar Rent-a-Car Iceland|access-date=}}</ref> Ireland, Latvia, Lithuania, Norway, Russia, Spain, Sweden, and Switzerland.
===North America=== The U.S. [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] (NHTSA) and [[Transport Canada]] allow display of a ''3PMSF'' symbol to indicate that the tire has exceeded the industry requirement from a reference (non-snow) tire.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.moderntiredealer.com/news/720104/cooper-recalls-7-067-discoverer-m-s-sport-tires | title = Cooper Recalls 7,067 Discoverer M+S Sport Tires | last = Editors | first = | date = February 21, 2017 | website = moderntiredealer.com | publisher = Modern Tire Dealer | access-date = 2017-03-26 | quote = }}</ref><ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.tracanada.ca/wintertirevideos/whatyoushouldknow.html | title = What You Should Know—Tires for Winter Driving | last = Editors | first = | date = | website = tracanada.ca | publisher = Tire and Rubber Association of Canada | access-date = 2017-03-26 | quote = }}</ref> As of 2016, snow tires were 3.6% of the US market and 35% of the Canadian market.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dudley|first1=David|title=The Joy and Terror of Urban Snow Driving|url=http://www.citylab.com/weather/2016/12/the-art-and-terror-of-urban-snow-driving/509648/|accessdate=13 December 2016|work=[[The Atlantic#CityLab|CityLab]]|date=6 December 2016}}</ref>
US states and Canadian provinces control the use of snow tires. No state<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.wintertpms.com/snow-tire-legislation-usa.html | title = Legislation for Snow Tires in the USA | last = Editors | first = | date = 2017 | website = bartecusa.com | publisher = Bartec USA LLC | access-date = 2017-03-26 | quote = }}</ref> or province (except for Quebec) requires snow tires.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.wintertpms.com/snow-tire-legislation-canada.html | title = Legislation for Snow Tires in Canada | last = Editors | first = | date = 2017 | website = bartecusa.com | publisher = Bartec USA LLC | access-date = 2017-03-26 | quote = }}</ref> They may require snow tires or chains only in certain areas during the winter: *''[[British Columbia]]'' – Snow tires are only required by law in certain "designated winter tire & chain-up routes" in mountainous regions. In these areas, motorists must use winter tires or carry tire chains.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/transportation/driving-and-cycling/traveller-information/seasonal/winter-driving/winter-tires-and-chains/winter-tire-and-chain-up-routes |title = Designated Winter Tire & Chain-up Routes |last = TranBC |first = |date = 2017 |website = gov.bc.ca |publisher = Transport British Columbia |access-date = 2017-03-26 |quote = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170327080555/http://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/transportation/driving-and-cycling/traveller-information/seasonal/winter-driving/winter-tires-and-chains/winter-tire-and-chain-up-routes |archivedate = 2017-03-27 |df = }}</ref> *''[[Alberta]]'' – [[Banff National Park]] or [[Jasper National Park]] require cars to have snow tires or tire chains between November 1 to March 31, or any other period during which the road is covered with snow or ice.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/C.R.C.,_c._1126/page-3.html#h-16 | title = National Parks Highway Traffic Regulations | last = Editors | first = | date = March 23, 2017 | website = justice.gc.ca | publisher = Government of Canada | access-date = 2017-03-26 | quote = }}</ref> *''[[Quebec]]'' – Winter tires or studded tires must be used from December 15 to March 15.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/quebec-winter-tire-deadline-1.3300751 | title = Quebec winter tires mandatory as of Dec. 15 | last = Editors | first = | date = November 3, 2015 | website = cbc.ca | publisher = CBC News | access-date = 2017-03-26 | quote = }}</ref>
The use of studded tires is regulated in the United States and Canada by individual states and provinces, as follows:<ref> {{cite web | url = http://drivinglaws.aaa.com/tag/studded-tires/ | title = Digest of Motor Laws—Studded tires | last = AAA | first = | date = 2017 | website = AAA.com | publisher = American Automobile Association | access-date = 2017-03-26 | quote = }}</ref> *''Unrestricted'' use – The following jurisdictions allow ''unrestricted'' use of studded snow tires; ''United States'': Colorado, Kentucky, North Carolina, Vermont, and Wyoming; ''Canada'': Alberta, Northwest Territories, Saskatchewan, and Yukon *''Prohibited'' – Studded snow tires may not be used in Hawaii, Mississippi or Puerto Rico. *''Seasonal'' use – All other states and provinces allow ''seasonal'' use of studded snow tires. In Alabama, Florida, Louisiana, Michigan and Texas, only rubber studs are allowed.
==References== {{reflist|3}}
{{Tires}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Snow Tires}} [[Category:Tires]] [[Category:Snow]] [[Category:Ice in transportation]] [[Category:Inclement weather management]] [[Category:Car safety]] [[Category:Automotive safety technologies]] [[Category:Winter|Tyres]]

revision.text:
'''Solona River''' is a name of several rivers in the Eastern Europe, especially in [[Ukraine]]. In the [[Ukrainian language]], the name means a salty (saline) river.
==Ukraine== * {{Interlanguage link multi|Solona River, Bezavluk|uk|3=Солона (притока Базавлуку)}}, a tributary of the [[Bezavluk River]] * [[Solona River, Yanchul]], a tributary of the [[Yanchul River]] * [[Solona River, Verkhnya Tersa (right)]], a tributary of the [[Verkhnya Tersa River]] * [[Solona River, Verkhnya Tersa (left)]], a tributary of the [[Verkhnya Tersa River]] * [[Solona River, Vovcha]], a tributary of the [[Vovcha River (Siversky Donets)|Vovcha River]], itself a tributary of the [[Siversky Donets]] * [[Solona River, Hnylyi Yalanets]], a tributary of the [[Hnylyi Yalanets River]]
==Romania== * [[Solona River, Romania]], a tributary of the [[Cristolțel River]]
{{river index}}

revision.text:
[[File:Tarangire Ecosystem.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Approximate outline of the Tarangire Ecosystem in northern Tanzania]]
The '''Tarangire''' '''Ecosystem''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|t|ɑːr|ɑː|n|ˈ|g|ɪr|eɪ}}) is a geographical region in Africa. It is located in northern [[Tanzania]] and extends between 2.5 and 5.5 degrees south latitudes and between 35.5 and 37 degrees east longitudes.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Lamprey|first=H.F.|date=1963|title=The Tarangire Game Reserve|url=|journal=Tanganyika Notes and Records|volume=60|pages=10–22|issue=|doi=|pmid=|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
The Tarangire Ecosystem hosts the second-largest population of [[Animal migration|migratory]] ungulates in East Africa and the largest population of elephants in northern Tanzania.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bolger|first=Douglas T.|last2=Newmark|first2=William D.|last3=Morrison|first3=Thomas A.|last4=Doak|first4=Daniel F.|title=The need for integrative approaches to understand and conserve migratory ungulates|url=http://refhub.elsevier.com/s0006-3207(16)30077-5/rf0015|journal=Ecology Letters|volume=0|pages=070926060247001––|doi=10.1111/j.1461-0248.2007.01109.x|year=2007}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Foley|first=Charles A. H.|last2=Faust|first2=Lisa J.|date=2010-04-01|title=Rapid population growth in an elephant Loxodonta africana population recovering from poaching in Tarangire National Park, Tanzania|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/oryx/article/rapid-population-growth-in-an-elephant-loxodonta-africana-population-recovering-from-poaching-in-tarangire-national-park-tanzania/2DADFFCB562E9553B1DF7688EB372FBF|journal=Oryx|volume=44|issue=2|pages=205–212|doi=10.1017/S0030605309990706|issn=1365-3008}}</ref>
The Tarangire Ecosystem is defined by the long distance migratory movements of [[Blue wildebeest|eastern white-bearded wildebeest]] and [[plains zebra]].<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lamprey|first=H. F.|date=1964-08-01|title=Estimation of the Large Mammal Densities, Biomass and Energy Exchange in the Tarangire Game Reserve and the Masai Steppe in Tanganyika|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2028.1964.tb00194.x/abstract|journal=African Journal of Ecology|language=en|volume=2|issue=1|pages=1–46|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2028.1964.tb00194.x|issn=1365-2028}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Borner|first=Markus|date=1985-04-01|title=The increasing isolation of Tarangire National Park|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/oryx/article/the-increasing-isolation-of-tarangire-national-park/149F6F39809E22BF3557D6DF044897E3|journal=Oryx|volume=19|issue=2|pages=91–96|doi=10.1017/S0030605300019797|issn=1365-3008}}</ref> It includes the dry season wildlife concentration area near the [[Tarangire River]] in [[Tarangire National Park]], and the wet-season dispersal and calving grounds to the north in the Northern Plains and to the east in Simanjiro Plains, spanning in total approximately 20,500 km<sup>2</sup> (7,900 sq mi).<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Bond|first=Monica L.|last2=Bradley|first2=Curtis M.|last3=Kiffner|first3=Christian|last4=Morrison|first4=Thomas A.|last5=Lee|first5=Derek E.|date=2017-05-26|title=A multi-method approach to delineate and validate migratory corridors|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10980-017-0537-4|journal=Landscape Ecology|volume=32|issue=8|language=en|pages=1–17|doi=10.1007/s10980-017-0537-4|issn=0921-2973}}</ref> Migratory animals must have access to both the dry-season water source in the park, and the nutrient-rich forage available only on the calving grounds outside the park to successfully raise their calves and maintain their high abundance.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Voeten|first=Margje M.|last2=Van De Vijver|first2=Claudius A.D.M.|last3=Olff|first3=Han|last4=Van Langevelde|first4=Frank|date=2010-03-01|title=Possible causes of decreasing migratory ungulate populations in an East African savannah after restrictions in their seasonal movements|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-2028.2009.01098.x/abstract|journal=African Journal of Ecology|language=en|volume=48|issue=1|pages=169–179|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2028.2009.01098.x|issn=1365-2028}}</ref>
The Tarangire Ecosystem is also known as the Masai Steppe, or the Tarangire-Manyara Ecosystem.
Tarangire has approximately 500 species of birds, and more than 60 species of larger mammal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.exoticbirding.com/tanzania/tarangire/checklist.html|title=Bird Checklist for Tarangire National Park|website=www.exoticbirding.com|access-date=2016-09-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://static1.squarespace.com/static/54929084e4b074c56b326d39/t/557069c1e4b00405e9c458f7/1433430465845/Mammals+of+TSL.pdf|title=Mammals of Tarangire National Park|last=Foley|first=C.|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Geography and climate == [[File:Baobabtre b3599.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Baobab tree, wildebeests, giraffes, and impala in Tarangire National Park]]
The area falls within the eastern branch of the [[East African Rift|East African Rift Valley]] which has widened and the valley floor fallen over the past few million years. About 250,000 years ago [[Lake Manyara]] and [[Lake Burunge]] were part of a larger lake called Proto-Manyara, a basin of internal drainage that lost water through evaporation and deep percolation. Subsequent rises in the Rift Valley floor changed drainage patterns and the lake was reduced in size and divided into the two shallow, alkali lakes currently seen.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title=Analysis of Migratory Movements of Large Mammals and their Interaction with Human Activities in the Tarangire Area in Tanzania as a Contribution to a Conservation and Sustainable Development Strategy|last=Tarangire Conservation Project|first=|publisher=|year=1997|isbn=|location=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Topography is now mainly low ridges of gneiss and pre-Cambrian rocks covered with well-drained, medium textured, stony soils. Large areas of valley bottoms are montmorillonite black cotton soils. Ancient lake sediments produced clay soils in the Proto-Manyara area. Minjingu Hill and Vilima Vitatu were islands in Proto-Manyara Lake and their phosphate deposits there are derived from accumulated waterbird feces. Volcanic ash deposits produce rich soils on the Northern Plains and Simanjiro Plains where migratory wildebeest and zebra find forage with the nutrients necessary for lactation and healthy calf growth.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":4" />
The current western boundary is the rift valley escarpment, the northern boundary is the Kenyan border near Lake Natron, the southern and eastern boundaries are not defined by any strict geographic features. Elevation ranges from about 1000 m in the southwest to 2660 m in the northeast.
Tarangire has a bimodal rainfall averaging 650 mm per annum, with short rains from November to February, long rains from March to May, and dry season from June to October. The rains, particularly the short rains, are very unreliable and often fail.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Msoffe|first=Fortunata U.|last2=Kifugo|first2=Shem C.|last3=Said|first3=Mohammed Y.|last4=Neselle|first4=Moses Ole|last5=Gardingen|first5=Paul Van|last6=Reid|first6=Robin S.|last7=Ogutu|first7=Joseph O.|last8=Herero|first8=Mario|last9=Leeuw|first9=Jan de|date=2011-12-01|title=Drivers and impacts of land-use change in the Maasai Steppe of northern Tanzania: an ecological, social and political analysis|journal=Journal of Land Use Science|volume=6|issue=4|pages=261–281|doi=10.1080/1747423X.2010.511682|issn=1747-423X}}</ref> Rainfall varies inter-annually, the standard deviation of the annual rainfall is equal to 37% of the mean annual rainfall. The inter-annual variation of monthly rainfall varies even more markedly, the standard deviation of monthly rainfall is 72% of the mean. This high variability in rainfall is also reflected in a high inter-annual variation of the length of the wet season. For example, the wet season lasted 38 days in 1983/1984 and 200 days in 1987/1988.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gereta|first=Emmanuel|last2=Meing’ataki|first2=Godwell Elias Ole|last3=Mduma|first3=Simon|last4=Wolanski|first4=Eric|title=The role of wetlands in wildlife migration in the Tarangire ecosystem, Tanzania|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11273-005-3499-2|journal=Wetlands Ecology and Management|language=en|volume=12|issue=4|pages=285–299|doi=10.1007/s11273-005-3499-2|issn=0923-4861|year=2004}}</ref>
The oldest known elephant to give birth to twins is found in Tarangire. A [https://www.asiliaafrica.com/trunk-twins-elephant-twins-born-in-tarangire/ recent birth of elephant twins] in the Tarangire National Park of Tanzania is a great example of how the birth of these two healthy and thriving twins can beat the odds.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.asiliaafrica.com/trunk-twins-elephant-twins-born-in-tarangire/|title=Trunk Twins : Elephant Twins Born in Tarangire {{!}} Asilia Africa|date=2018-04-06|work=Asilia Africa|access-date=2018-04-06|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== History == [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 105-DOA0805, Deutsch-Ostafrika, Gruppe von Massai.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Picture of Massai from early 1900s]]
Between the sixteenth and nineteenth centuries, the Maa-speaking pastoral people expanded into the area, replacing other pastoral groups like Nilotes and farming Bantu groups.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=pWHbh59FBNcC&pg=PP1&dq=Maasailand+Ecology:+Pastoralists+Development+and+Wildlife+Conservation|title=Maasailand Ecology: Pastoralist Development and Wildlife Conservation in Ngorongoro, Tanzania|last=Homewood|first=K. M.|last2=Rodgers|first2=W. A.|last3=|first3=|date=1991|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=9780521607490|location=|pages=|language=en|via=}}</ref> By 1880 the Maasai reached their greatest extent. Around 1900 they suffered pleuro-pneumonia and small pox diseases that killed many. At the same time the outbreak of the rinderpest decimated Maasai livestock and wildlife.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.ucpress.edu/book.php?isbn=9780520273191|title=The Gnu's World|last=Estes|first=R.D.|publisher=UC Press|year=2014|isbn=|location=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
The colonial period of 1880s to 1950s saw the displacement of Maasai from lands with high potential for agricultural development by the European farmers/settlers.<ref name=":3" /> Many game parks were created at the same time, often evicting pastoralists from key dry season grazing areas and watering points. Because of the abundant water and pasture in the Tarangire ecosystem, it had a reputation as one of the best pastoral areas in Tanzania. Many herders who were evicted from the Serengeti National Park in the 1950s relocated to this area.<ref name=":2" />
Tanzania became independent in 1961 and most of the British colonial administration/legislation was adopted by the new government. In the 1960s and 1970s the [[rinderpest]] that had previously killed many wildlife and livestock species was controlled. The control of rinderpest resulted in the increased numbers of wildebeest in the Serengeti ecosystem. This pushed Maasai into Tarangire area to avoid contact with wildebeest calving areas in the short grass-plains. Such areas are associated with the spread of [[Bovine malignant catarrhal fever|Malignant Catarrhal Fever]] that affects cattle. Between 1962 and 1963 the worst drought in 50 years hit most parts of the country including Tarangire area and killed many wildlife and livestock.<ref name=":0" />
In 1967 agriculture was promoted as the backbone of the national economy. Large-scale farms like the Lolkisale bean farms were established in Tarangire to produce crops for export as well as for national reserves during droughts and food shortage. Human population increased in Tarangire area due both to natural increase and immigration of agriculturists from nearby regions of Kilimanjaro and Arusha. This displaced Maasai pastoralists and wildlife from the best rangelands into more marginal areas.<ref name=":2" />
In 1970, the Tarangire Game Reserve was upgraded to become Tarangire National Park. By the mid 1980s the movement of commercial interests and farmers into the area had expanded, blocking many traditional migratory routes for wildlife.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Homewood|first=K.|last2=Lambin|first2=E. F.|last3=Coast|first3=E.|last4=Kariuki|first4=A.|last5=Kikula|first5=I.|last6=Kivelia|first6=J.|last7=Said|first7=M.|last8=Serneels|first8=S.|last9=Thompson|first9=M.|date=2001-10-23|title=Long-term changes in Serengeti-Mara wildebeest and land cover: Pastoralism, population, or policies?|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/98/22/12544|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=98|issue=22|pages=12544–12549|doi=10.1073/pnas.221053998|issn=0027-8424|pmc=60090|pmid=11675492}}</ref>
In 2001, the Tanzanian government turned over the National Ranching Company land at Manyrara Ranch to the Tanzania Land Conservation Trust to help conserve the wildlife migration corridor between Tarangire National Park and the calving grounds to the north on the Gelai Plains.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Goldman|first=Mara J.|last2=Pinho|first2=Joana Roque de|last3=Perry|first3=Jennifer|date=2013-10-01|title=Beyond ritual and economics: Maasai lion hunting and conservation politics|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/oryx/article/beyond-ritual-and-economics-maasai-lion-hunting-and-conservation-politics/5872D7AE49E17FB99A13BDC9D9657A8D|journal=Oryx|volume=47|issue=4|pages=490–500|doi=10.1017/S0030605312000907|issn=0030-6053}}</ref> Conservation easements are being used as conservation tools on the calving grounds east of Tarangire National Park on the Simanjiro Plains.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nelson|first=Fred|last2=Foley|first2=Charles|last3=Foley|first3=Lara S.|last4=Leposo|first4=Abraham|last5=Loure|first5=Edward|last6=Peterson|first6=David|last7=Peterson|first7=Mike|last8=Peterson|first8=Thad|last9=Sachedina|first9=Hassan|date=2010-02-01|title=Payments for Ecosystem Services as a Framework for Community-Based Conservation in Northern Tanzania|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1523-1739.2009.01393.x/abstract|journal=Conservation Biology|language=en|volume=24|issue=1|pages=78–85|doi=10.1111/j.1523-1739.2009.01393.x|pmid=20121844|issn=1523-1739}}</ref> Land-use planning informed by wildlife survey data is being tried to help conserve pastoral rangelands, wildlife migration routes,<ref name=":5" /> and calving grounds in the Northern Plains.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wildnatureinstitute.org/corridor-campaign.html|title=Northern Plains Migration Habitat Connectivity Protection Campaign|website=Wild Nature Institute|access-date=2016-09-15}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.wildnatureinstitute.org/corridor-campaign.html Wild Nature Institute] * [http://www.wcstanzania.org/tarangire.htm Wildlife Conservation Society]

revision.comment: Lapse rates in table were of the wrong sign. Lapse rate is *decrease* of T with height.
revision.text:
{{distinguish|International Standard Atmosphere}} {{Comparison_US_standard_atmosphere_1962.svg}} The '''U.S. Standard Atmosphere''' is an [[atmospheric models|atmospheric model]] of how the [[pressure]], [[temperature]], [[density]], and [[viscosity]] of the [[Earth's atmosphere]] change over a wide range of [[altitude]]s or [[elevation]]s. The model, based on an existing international standard, was first published in 1958 by the U.S. Committee on Extension to the Standard Atmosphere, and was updated in 1962, 1966, and 1976. It is largely consistent in methodology with the [[International Standard Atmosphere]], differing mainly in the assumed temperature distribution at higher altitudes. [[Image:Atmospheric composition Langley.svg|thumb|250px|Visualization of composition by volume of Earth's atmosphere. Water vapor is not included, as this is highly variable. Each tiny cube (such as the one representing krypton) has one millionth of the volume of the entire block. Data is from [http://www.nasa.gov/centers/langley/pdf/245893main_MeteorologyTeacherRes-Ch2.r4.pdf NASA Langley].]] ==Methodology== The USSA [[mathematical model]] divides the atmosphere into layers with an assumed linear distribution of [[absolute temperature]] ''T'' against [[geopotential altitude]] ''h''.Gyatt, Graham (2006-01-14): [http://nebula.wsimg.com/ab321c1edd4fa69eaa94b5e8e769b113?AccessKeyId=AF1D67CEBF3A194F66A3&disposition=0&alloworigin=1 "The Standard Atmosphere"]. A mathematical model of the 1976 U.S. Standard Atmosphere. The other two values (pressure ''P'' and density ''ρ'') are computed by [[simultaneous equations model|simultaneously solving the equations]] resulting from: * the [[vertical pressure variation]], which relates pressure, density and geopotential altitude (using a standard pressure of {{convert|101325|Pa|psi|sigfig=5}} at [[sea level|mean sea level]] as a [[boundary value problem|boundary condition]]): :: \frac{dP}{dh} = - \rho g , and * the [[ideal gas law]] in [[mole (unit)|molar]] form, which relates pressure, density, and temperature: :: \ P = \rho R_{\rm specific}T at each geopotential altitude, where ''g'' is the [[Standard_gravity|standard acceleration of gravity]], and ''R''specific is the [[Gas constant#Specific gas constant|specific gas constant]] for dry air. Air density must be calculated in order to solve for the pressure, and is used in calculating [[dynamic pressure]] for moving vehicles. [[Viscosity#Dynamic (shear) viscosity|Dynamic viscosity]] is an empirical function of temperature, and [[Viscosity#Kinematic viscosity|kinematic viscosity]] is calculated by dividing dynamic viscosity by the density. Thus the standard consists of a tabulation of values at various altitudes, plus some formulas by which those values were derived. To allow modeling [[list of places on land with elevations below sea level|conditions below mean sea level]], the troposphere is actually extended to {{convert|-2000|ft|m|sp=us}}, where the temperature is {{convert|66.1|F|C}}, pressure is {{convert|15.79|psi|Pa}}, and density is {{convert|1.2985|kg/m3|lb/ft3|sp=us|disp=flip}}. ==1962 version== The basic assumptions made for the 1962 version were:{{cite book |author=Tuve, George Lewis |author2=Bolz, Ray E. |title=CRC handbook of tables for applied engineering science |publisher=[[CRC Press]] |location=Boca Raton |date=1973 |isbn=0-8493-0252-8 }} *air is a clean, dry, [[perfect gas]] mixture ([[heat capacity|cp/cv]] = 1.40) *[[molecular weight]] to 90 km of 28.9644 (C-12 scale) *principal sea-level constituents are assumed to be: ** [[Nitrogen|N2]]–78.084% ** [[Oxygen|O2]]–20.9476% ** [[Argon|Ar]]–0.934% ** [[Carbon dioxide|CO2]]–0.0314% ** [[Neon|Ne]]–0.001818% ** [[Helium|He]]–0.000524% ** [[Methane|CH4]]–0.0002%. *assigned mean conditions at [[sea level]] are as follows : **[[Pressure|P]] = 14.696 [[Pounds per square inch|psi]] = 2116.22 psf = 101325 Pa = 29.92 In-Hg = 0.1013250 MN/m2 **[[Temperature|T]] = 59 °F = 518.67 °R = 15 °C = 288.15 K **[[Density|ρ]] = 0.0764734 lb/(cu ft) = 1.225 0 kg/m3 **[[Earth's gravity|g]] = 32.174 1 ft/s2 = 9.80665 m/s2 **[[gas constant|R]] = 1545.31 ft lb/(lbmol °R) = 8.31432 J/(mol K). ==1976 version== This is the most recent version and differs from previous versions only above 32 km: {| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan="2"|Subscript ''b'' ! colspan="2"|Geopotential
altitude above MSLU.S. Standard Atmosphere, 1962, U.S. Government Printing Office, Washington, D.C., 1962 ! colspan="2"|Static pressure ! rowspan="2"|Standard temperature
(K) ! colspan="2"|Temperature Lapse Rate |- ! (m) !! (ft)!! (pascals) !! (inHg) !! (K/m) !! (K/ft) |- | align="center" |0 | align="center" |0 | align="center" |0 | align="center" |101325 | align="center" |29.92126 | align="center" |288.15 | align="center" |0.0065 | align="center" |0.0019812 |- | align="center" |1 | align="center" |11,000 | align="center" |36,089 | align="center" |22632.1 | align="center" |6.683245 | align="center" |216.65 | align="center" |0.0 | align="center" |0.0 |- | |- | align="center" |3 | align="center" |32,000 | align="center" |104,987 | align="center" |868.019 | align="center" |0.2563258 | align="center" |228.65 | align="center" |-0.0028 | align="center" Atmosphere] [[Category:Atmosphere of Earth]] [[Category:Atmospheric thermodynamics]]

In [[geophysics]], '''vertical seismic profile''' ('''VSP''') is a technique of [[seismic]] measurements used for correlation with surface seismic data. The defining characteristic of a VSP (of which there are many types) is that either the energy source, or the detectors (or sometimes both) are in a borehole. In the most common type of VSP, [[Hydrophone]]s, or more often [[geophone]]s or [[accelerometers]], in the [[borehole]] record reflected seismic energy originating from a seismic source at the surface.
There are numerous methods for acquiring a vertical seismic profile (VSP). Zero-offset VSPs (A) have sources close to the wellbore directly above receivers. Offset VSPs (B) have sources some distance from the receivers in the wellbore. Walkaway VSPs (C) feature a source that is moved to progressively farther offset and receivers held in a fixed location. Walk-above VSPs (D) accommodate the recording geometry of a deviated well, having each receiver in a different lateral position and the source directly above the receiver. Salt-proximity VSPs (E) are reflection surveys to help define a salt-sediment interface near a wellbore by using a source on top of a salt dome away from the drilling rig. Drill-noise VSPs (F), also known as seismic-while-drilling (SWD) VSPs, use the noise of the drill bit as the source and receivers laid out along the ground. Multi-offset VSPs (G) involve a source some distance from numerous receivers in the wellbore.<ref>{{cite web|title=Diagram of VSP configurations|url=http://www.glossary.oilfield.slb.com/en/Terms/v/en/~/media/PublicMedia/thumbOGL98159.ashx|publisher=Schlumberger|accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.glossary.oilfield.slb.com/en/Terms/v/vertical_seismic_profile.aspx Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary: vertical seismic profile]
[[Category:Geophysics]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Vilma Hunt | birth_name = Vilma Dalton-Webb | birth_date = {{Birth date|1926|11|15|mf=yes}} | birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Sydney|Sydney, New South Wales]], [[Australia]]}} | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=y|2012|12|29|1926|11|15}} | death_place = [[Gloucester, Massachusetts]], [[United States]] | spouse = Edward Hunt | children = Margaret Hunt
William Hunt
Louise Rounds
Kitty Hunt
Martine Lebret | alma_mater = [[University of Sydney]]
[[Radcliffe Institute]] | imagesize = | }} '''Vilma Rose Hunt''' (November 15, 1926 – December 29, 2012) was a scientist noted for research into [[Radiation protection|radiation]] and [[Occupational safety and health|workplace safety]] for women. After beginning a dentistry career in [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], Hunt traveled to the United States where she earned her A.M. in Physical Anthropology at [[Radcliffe College]] and began researching [[public health]] and [[radiation biology]].{{cite web| title = Hunt, Vilma R.. Papers of Vilma R. Hunt, 1952–1993: A Finding Aid| publisher = Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University| date = 1952| url = http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch00644| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} In 1964, Hunt discovered that [[polonium 210]] is a natural contaminant of [[tobacco]], providing additional evidence for the link between [[smoking]] and [[bronchial cancer]].{{cite web| last = Hunt| first = Vilma| title = Polonium-210: A Volatile Radioelement in Cigarettes| publisher = Science| date = January 17, 1964| url = https://www.jstor.org.ezp-prod1.hul.harvard.edu/stable/1712451?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents| accessdate = March 24, 2017}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 1974, she wrote a 121-page report on workplace hazards for pregnant women, which made the front page of the ''[[New York Times]]''.{{cite web| last = Burnham| first = David| title = Rise in Birth Defects Laid to Job Hazards| publisher = The New York Times| date = March 14, 1976| url = https://www.nytimes.com/1976/03/14/archives/rise-in-birth-defects-laid-to-job-hazards-studies-attribute.html| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} She published a book, ''Work and the Health of Women'', in 1979.{{cite web| last = Feldscher| first = Karen| title = In Memoriam: Vilma Hunt, former HSPH scientist, radiation expert, feminist| publisher = Harvard T. H. Chan School of Public Health| date = January 22, 2013| url = https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/features/in-memorium-vilma-hunt/| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} From 1979 to 1981, Hunt served as an administrator for the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]], enacting public health solutions to environmental contamination at sites like [[Love Canal]], New York, and [[Three Mile Island Nuclear Generating Station]], Pennsylvania.{{cite web| last = Feldscher| first = Karen| title = In Memoriam: Vilma Hunt, former HSPH scientist, radiation expert, feminist| publisher = Harvard T. H. Chan School of Public Health| date = January 22, 2013| url = https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/features/in-memorium-vilma-hunt/| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} Hunt retired in Gloucester in 1985,{{cite web| last = McCarthy| first = Gail| title = Gloucester Times Obituaries| publisher = Gloucester Times| url = http://obituaries.gloucestertimes.com/story/2012-772480921/print| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} though she served as an environmental consultant and visiting lecturer until her death.{{cite web| title = Hunt, Vilma R.. Papers of Vilma R. Hunt, 1952–1993: A Finding Aid| publisher = Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University| date = 1952| url = http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch00644| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} ==Personal life== Vilma Hunt was born in [[Sydney]] on November 15, 1926.{{cite web| title = Hunt, Vilma R.. Papers of Vilma R. Hunt, 1952–1993: A Finding Aid| publisher = Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University| date = 1952| url = http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch00644| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} She is the daughter of Margaret Rose (Lynch) Dalton-Webb and William Dalton-Webb, an electrician. When Vilma was seven years old, the Dalton-Webb family moved to [[Kempsey, New South Wales]]. She attended public school and graduated from high school in 1942. After graduation, during [[World War II]], she enlisted in the women's auxiliary branch of the [[Royal Australian Air Force]]. In 1952, Vilma travelled to [[Boston]] to study dentistry. She met Edward Eyre Hunt, Jr. at the Forsyth Dental Infirmary. They married in 1952, moved to [[Gloucester, Massachusetts]], and had four children: Margaret, William, Louise, Catherine and Martine (a foster daughter). Margaret would later become the chair of the women and gender studies department at [[Amherst College]]. Vilma and Edward retired in 1985.{{cite web| last = Lawrence| first = J.M.| title = Vilma Hunt; pioneered research into smoking, worksites| publisher = The Boston Globe| date = January 13, 2017| url = https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/obituaries/2013/01/17/vilma-hunt-gloucester-researched-dangers-smoking-and-environmental-hazards/PrjklLL0B2rKFMKNWu9YjJ/story.html| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} ==Career== ===Dentistry=== Vilma Hunt began her career as a dentist. She earned her Bachelor of Dental Surgery at the [[University of Sydney]] in 1950, and served as a Junior Dental Officer with the [[New Zealand Department of Health]] from 1950–1952.{{cite web| title = Hunt, Vilma R.. Papers of Vilma R. Hunt, 1952–1993: A Finding Aid| publisher = Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University| date = 1952| url = http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch00644| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} She accepted a scholarship to study dentistry at [[Harvard University]] in 1952.{{cite web| last = Lawrence| first = J.M.| title = Vilma Hunt; pioneered research into smoking, worksites| publisher = The Boston Globe| date = January 13, 2017| url = https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/obituaries/2013/01/17/vilma-hunt-gloucester-researched-dangers-smoking-and-environmental-hazards/PrjklLL0B2rKFMKNWu9YjJ/story.html| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} ===Anthropology and public health=== After studying, interning, and lecturing on dentistry for several years, Hunt began studying anthropology. She earned her A.M. in Physical Anthropology from Radcliffe College in 1958 and began to conduct research with the [[Radcliffe Institute for Independent Study]], from 1961–1963, and the [[Harvard School of Public Health]], from 1962–1966. She received additional training in radiation biology from the [[Argonne National Laboratory]], in [[Illinois]], in the summer of 1963.{{cite web| title = Hunt, Vilma R.. Papers of Vilma R. Hunt, 1952–1993: A Finding Aid| publisher = Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University| date = 1952| url = http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch00644| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} While at HSPH, Hunt tested a cigarette butt for radiation, on a hunch.{{cite web| last = Lawrence| first = J.M.| title = Vilma Hunt; pioneered research into smoking, worksites| publisher = The Boston Globe| date = January 13, 2017| url = https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/obituaries/2013/01/17/vilma-hunt-gloucester-researched-dangers-smoking-and-environmental-hazards/PrjklLL0B2rKFMKNWu9YjJ/story.html| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} She discovered high levels of Polonium-201, a radioactive element, and launched an investigation alongside colleague Edward P. Radford. The pair published their findings, titled "Polonium-210: A Volatile Radioelement in Cigarettes" in [[Science (journal)|''Science'']].{{cite web| last = Hunt| first = Vilma| title = Polonium-210: A Volatile Radioelement in Cigarettes| publisher = Science| date = January 17, 1964| url = https://www.jstor.org.ezp-prod1.hul.harvard.edu/stable/1712451?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents| accessdate = March 24, 2017}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The article came out on January 17, 1964––just six days after the [[surgeon general]]'s report on the dangers of smoking was released.{{cite web| last = Kohlstedt| first = Sally| title = Science and the American Century: Readings from "Isis"| publisher = University of Chicago Press| date = March 24, 2013| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=INyesnoT6VUC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} In 1964, Hunt was elected to [[Phi Beta Kappa Society|Phi Beta Kappa]].{{cite web| title = Hunt, Vilma R.. Papers of Vilma R. Hunt, 1952–1993: A Finding Aid| publisher = Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University| date = 1952| url = http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch00644| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} ===Academia=== Hunt taught and lectured for over three decades. From 1967–1969, she served as Assistant Professor of Environmental Health at the [[Yale University School of Medicine]]. From 1969–1972, she served as Assistant and Associate Professor of Environmental Health at [[Pennsylvania State University]], where she was granted tenure in 1972. She would return to become Professor of Environmental Health from 1982–1985 before leaving to become a Mellon Research Fellow at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] in 1984. She received the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]] award in 1985.{{cite web| title = Hunt, Vilma R.. Papers of Vilma R. Hunt, 1952–1993: A Finding Aid| publisher = Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University| date = 1952| url = http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch00644| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} ===Advocacy for Women=== Outside of the classroom, Hunt conducted research into [[chemical hazard]]s in the workplace, particularly in relation to [[reproductive health]]. On April 30, 1974, she published a 121-page report for the [[Department of Health, Education, and Welfare]] titled "Occupational Problems of Pregnant Women." Within the report, she wrote "We are all responsible for the health of future generations and we can no longer ignore a fact of life––reproduction and work are women's lot." Elsewhere, she details the poor working conditions and hazardous exposures present in factories and shows their correlation to high infant mortality rates, birth defects, and miscarriages. Differing from previous research on the subject, she also includes male fertility in her research, demonstrating that high levels of radiation negatively affect male sperm count. Her report was read across the nation, and on March 14, 1976, it made the front page of New York Times.{{cite web| last = Burnham| first = David| title = Rise in Birth Defects Laid to Job Hazards | publisher = The New York Times| date = March 24, 2017| url = https://www.nytimes.com/1976/03/14/archives/rise-in-birth-defects-laid-to-job-hazards-studies-attribute.html?_r=0| accessdate = February 17, 2007 }} A few years later, in 1979, Hunt published her first (and only completed) novel, ''A Brief History of Women Workers and Hazards in the Workplace''. In it, she discussed changing attitudes towards women's' health concerns and the treatment of women in factories, and called for [[Labour regulations|labor regulations]] to protect women from [[benzene]], a toxic chemical. She commented on how quickly the presence of women in [[lead]] factories declined, after it was exposed that lead had [[Lead poisoning|disastrous effects]] on children and the reproductive system. Hunt attributed the slow-changing pace of laws around benzene factories to the lack of definitive research on whether benzene affects the fetus. Hunt criticized the government's slow action and called for the improvement of factory conditions, rather than the removal of women from the industry.{{cite web| last = Hunt| first = Vilma| title = A Brief History of Women Workers and Hazards in the Workplace | publisher = Feminist Studies, Inc. | date = March 24, 1979| url = https://www.nytimes.com/1976/03/14/archives/rise-in-birth-defects-laid-to-job-hazards-studies-attribute.html?_r=0| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} ===Environmental protection=== Hunt also worked in conservation. She served on the Science Advisory Board of the United States Environmental Protection Agency from 1978–1979, where she was tasked with investigating and explaining chemical poisoning and radiation at environmental contamination sites, including the now-infamous Love Canal, NY, and Three Mile, PA. ===Retirement=== After she retired in 1985, Hunt became active in Gloucester local government, and served as a curator at the Magnolia Historical Society. She researched the history of [[uranium]], and with the help of Harvard student Melissa Inouye, she began a book on the topic. At the time of Hunt's death in 2012, the text was incomplete.{{cite web| last = Feldscher| first = Karen| title = In Memoriam: Vilma Hunt, former HSPH scientist, radiation expert, feminist| publisher = Harvard T. H. Chan School of Public Health| date = January 22, 2013| url = https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/features/in-memorium-vilma-hunt/| accessdate = March 24, 2017 }} == References == {{reflist|30em}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hunt, Vilma Rose}} [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Australian scientists]] [[Category:21st-century Australian scientists]] [[Category:20th-century Australian non-fiction writers]] [[Category:20th-century Australian women writers]] [[Category:20th-century women scientists]] [[Category:21st-century women scientists]] [[Category:Australian women scientists]] [[Category:Radcliffe College alumni]] [[Category:Australian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:People from Sydney]] [[Category:People from Gloucester, Massachusetts]] [[Category:University of Sydney alumni]] [[Category:Australian dentists]] [[Category:Yale School of Medicine faculty]] [[Category:Pennsylvania State University faculty]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology fellows]] [[Category:Radiation]] [[Category:New Zealand dentists]] [[Category:Royal Australian Air Force personnel of World War II]]

{{out of date|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=November 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}}
The '''World Hereford Council''' is the international breeding authority on [[Hereford cattle]], existing for the promotion of breed excellence and the cultivation of global trade in Hereford genetics. Originally based in England, at the [[Hereford Cattle Society]], the Council was established in 1951 as a response to the increasingly widespread international export and breeding of Hereford cattle, and the need to maintain a global authority connecting Hereford cattle to the original English herd book.<ref>[http://www.herefordcattle.org/about-us/history/ Hereford Cattle Society: History]</ref><ref>[http://www.herefords.com/ World Hereford Council Constitution], Constitution and Rules.</ref>
The Headquarters of the Council are based in the country of residence of the Secretary General (Uruguay, as of 2015), and move with each new election.<ref>Sociedad Criadores de Hereford del Uruguay. [http://www.hereforduruguay2016.org/ World Hereford Council] 2015</ref>
The World Hereford Council aims to advance the mutual interests of pedigree Hereford breeders on a worldwide scale, to act as an international breed authority, and to act as mediator in any disagreements or conflicts that may occur between any of the member countries. Structurally, the Council is led by a Secretary General, voted in by the twenty member countries (each nominating two representatives).
==Member Countries== *[[American Hereford Association]] – United States of America *Asociacion Argentina Criadores de Hereford – Argentina *Herefords Australia Ltd. – Australia *Associação Brasileira de Hereford e Braford – Brazil *[http://www.hereford.ca Canadian Hereford Association]] – Canada *Danish Hereford Cattle Society – Denmark *Animal Breeders Association of Estonia – Estonia *Finnish Hereford Society – Finland *German Hereford Association – Germany *Hungarian Hereford Association – Hungary *Irish Hereford Breed Society – Ireland *Republican Chamber of Hereford Breed – Kazakhstan www.herefords.kz *Dutch Hereford Society – Netherlands *New Zealand Hereford Association Inc. – New Zealand *Norway Hereford Association – Norway *South African Hereford Breeders' Society – South Africa *Swedish Hereford Association – Sweden *IG Swiss Hereford – Switzerland *[[Hereford Cattle Society]] – United Kingdom *Sociedad Criadores de Hereford del Uruguay – Uruguay <ref>[http://www.herefords.com/ World Hereford Council Members and Non-Member Countries], Member Countries.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.herefords.com/ The World Hereford Council]
